headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hi, good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, and I'm the Head of Investor Relations for Cellnex. I would like to thank you for joining us today for our full year results conference call. I'm joined today by Tobías Gimeno, CEO; José Manuel Aisa,
componenttext: Hi, good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, and I'm the Head of Investor Relations for Cellnex. I would like to thank you for joining us today for our full year results conference call. I'm joined today by Tobías Gimeno, CEO; José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, they will lead today's presentation. We have, earlier today, posted our presentation, which we will refer to throughout our prepared remarks, and then, we'll open the line for a Q&A session. So now I'll hand over to Tobías Gimeno. Mr. Tobías.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones for the period on Slide #4.We have again posted solid set of results based on 4 pillars. Number 1, our recurrent leverage
componenttext:
Well, Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones for the period on Slide #4.
We have again posted solid set of results based on 4 pillars. Number 1, our recurrent leverage free cash flow has increased by more than 60% since our IPO, May 2015. Second, we have generated organic growth ahead of our guidance. Third, our business profile has dramatically improved as a result of the development of our European platform. And last, we continue to have a robust balance sheet with flexibility to continue capturing new growth opportunities.
On Slide #5, you can see the stronger performance of our key volumetrics. We have adjusted EBITDA growing at 33% per year and a record and leverage free cash flow per share growing at around 30% per year during the last couple of years.
Moving to Slide #6. Here is important to highlight that in the beginning of 2016, we guided to 3% to 4% organic growth and we came in ahead of that guidance, which show of our current operations. Including the change of during 2016, total PoPs have increased by 19% and our consolidated customer ratio by 6%. Additionally, have increased 13% and we expect this new activity to become a meaningful contributor to Cellnex Telecom infrastructure service going forward. In terms of our organic growth drivers, you can see on the Slide #7, our view for new organic PoPs as well as the progress of our commissioning and Build to Suit program. New PoPs from multi-tenancy are expected to be generated at a similar rate as the guidance provided last year. Our decommissioning program shows 25% progress, including agreements or redesign and a 73% progress for our Build to Suit program, including our last transaction with Telecom in January 2017.
And additionally, our efficiency program, I can say you that it is on track and we have recently signed a commercial balance sheet agreement with JC to strengthen our position in the Small Cell business. And the CFO will later provide you more details on both
Moving to Slide #8, I would like to emphasize that as a result of our recent bills, we have dramatically improved our business risk profile by diversifying both in term of geographies and exposure to new high quality customers. It is also worth mentioning that pro forma basis, it means including the full year affect of our bills announced in 2016 and 2017, France, 62% of our revenues will be generated by Telecom infrastructure services and that our current backlog represents today 14 years of revenues or 8x our net debt.
On Slide #9, you can see the result of our geographical diversification efforts. With around half of our adjusted EBITDA to be generated outside of Spain, again on a pro forma basis. While Cellnex have become a key player in terms of number of towers worldwide. Our efforts to create a European platform translate into demand on the right-hand side with the last example being the agreement with recently reached with telecom. Let me please take the opportunity of summarize on Slide #10, the key characteristics of our last project in France. First of all, let me highlight the high quality of the assets; second one, the high visibility of the revenues; third, the new paradigm created in the tower industry by shifting from the classic Master Lease Agreement to an innovative master service agreement; fourth, our tax-efficient structure; fifth, efficient cash flow -- outflows  sorry, providing financial flexibility; and sixth, the validation of our discipline international expansion strategy. On a run-rate basis, with all sites have been transferred and build by 2022, we are expecting an EBITDA contribution of EUR 61 million per year.
I will not go through the details on Slide #11. But I would highlight at least 4 key ideas. First, thanks to this deal, we are beginning the second largest in the tower operator in France, gaining a scale from our first investment in September 2016. Second, increasing our presence in a highly dynamic market as it is France. The third, the effectiveness of our portfolio offers high quality organic growth potential. And forth, we're acquiring assets in areas with very high barriers to entry around 34 services models to build new site in the main cities of France.
Moving to Slide #12, just a few words from our strong balance sheet with headroom to continue pursuing accretive M&A. We have close to EUR 2 billion in cash and available debt. Our long-term and fixed capital structure in place at attractive terms. And for flexibility that will allow us to optimize available funding alternatives. We will remain disciplined and stick to our criteria. There are ample opportunities available and we have demonstrate with recent opportunities, we will not overpay. Before moving to José Manuel's section let me please highlight in the Slide #13, that today we're presenting again a solid set of results. We are posting strong organic growth and progress on our additional value enhancing initiatives. We are taking the first step to be common European leader in the and small sector. We are creating a European platform, executing value accretive acquisitions that improve our business profile. We have a robust capital structure in place, enough firepower is still available to continue growing while optimizing funding alternatives. We continue to pursue growth opportunities with discipline and with selective M&A approach, we are successfully integrating our recent portfolios into Cellnex and Cellnex is today recognized as the player best positioning to consolidate the European tower landscape.
Now, please allow me to hand over to José Manuel Aisa, our CFO and M&A Director, who will go through our 2016 business and financial performance. So, please José Manuel.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tobías. Good afternoon. As a reminder, please note that additional information can be obtained on the Investor Relations sections of our website, where there is a detailed file and should we also accounts of the company.So if now we go to sl
componenttext:
Thank you, Tobías. Good afternoon. As a reminder, please note that additional information can be obtained on the Investor Relations sections of our website, where there is a detailed file and should we also accounts of the company.
So if now we go to slide 15, you can see here the evolution of PoPs and our consolidated ratio, with increases mainly explained by consistent organic growth and change of parametric. We have managed to add more than 900 dynamic PoPs in the period, reaching alternative ratio of 1.62, including M&A. Additionally, we are pursuing new organic growth opportunities in all business areas with a special mention to framework agreements with mobile operators entering new markets, the commissioning and Build to Suit projects and other recent agreements with JCDecaux to strengthen our position in this more sense market. This balance sheet applies one opportunity arise in Spain and Italy for initial period of 18 months. with current all or when a new tender process is launched manage advertising sites and on our preferred partner approach on cost exiting capabilities and adding on top of that our own capabilities to increase the value position.
Moving to slide 15, you can see here the progress of our efficiency plan. As anticipated last year, the main contributor to this program is our site management project, with around 30% of the targeted savings annually achieved. We have CapEx of EUR 31 million between and land acquisition with paybacks of 5 years and average saving around of about 20%, with a resulting contract land begin 15 years. We're also making good progress on our additional initiatives with around 50% of the targeted savings annually achieved. Our ultimate objective for the efficiency plan will be for savings to offset higher future cost due to a pricing and increased operating activity, so we can show a flat performance on a like-for-like basis going forward.
On the next slide, benefit explanation of our adjusted EBITDA evolution. You can see how the negative impact of the DTT single in 2015 is more than offset by the of the new TV channels. Together, with organic growth contribution and change of parametric, explaining the strong adjusted EBITDA increase in the year of 23%, in other words, EUR 290 million of adjusted EBITDA.
If we now focus on the adjusted EBITDA margin evolution on the next slide, operating leverage coming from organic growth increases our margin by 1% by additional 2% and if we adjust for pass-through constant revenues, we end up with an adjusted EBITDA margin of 43%.
Slide 19. We will now focus on our capital allocation for the year. We have devoted 90% of our total investment to M&A with 80% allocated to expansion CapEx. We deploy organic growth CapEx with a strict and levered IRR. And you can see the majority have been dedicated in 2015 to our efficiency plan.
Slide 20, regarding capital structure. Our debt maturities profile as of February 2015 present the first maturity or an average maturity of around 7 years with no material refinancing required before 2022, protection against potential interest rates hikes due to the fixed cost nature of our 
Slide 21. There, we provide an updated snapshot of our capital structure after our last bond issued in January. We have long-term capital structure in place as attractive terms with EUR 1.8 billion of liquidity between cash and available credit lines.
Let me now explain on the slide 22, our recurring levered free cash flow generation in the period. I would like to start by highlighting that the cash conversion ratio of EBITDA into recurring levered free cash flow in the period has been strong 87%. With the total figure increasing 30%, when compared to the recurring levered free cash flow of 2015.
Looking now to revenues, the contribution from all the different businesses line increase with our very will contain cost base, leading to an adjusted EBITDA growth of 23% when compared to last year. Maintenance CapEx, if we now see our guidance of 3% of revenues and our change in working capital is positive due to our one-off revenue collection measures, but expected to be going forward in line with our guidance.
Interest rates reflects our capital structure as of December with coupons in Q3 reflecting the implementation of tax management measures. All-in-all, we are posting a 15% revenue growth, which implies almost our recurring levered free cash flow growth when compared to last year.
Moving now to our balance sheet on slide 23. Cellnex leverage for the period has been 4.6x net EBITDA after investing more than EUR 700 million in the year. Our balance sheet reflects the increase in fixed asset due to our recent acquisitions, recurring net profit, adjusted for one-off noncash task tax effect last year increases 38% and net interest increase mainly due to cost in the year.
On the remuneration, we will pay EUR 22 million in 2017, 10% increase over the dividend paid in 2016.
Moving to M&A activity in 2015 -- '16, sorry. On slide 24, what we believe is our new in the tower industry. Our ability to create master service agreement with our clients from the scratch, making sure these services were not be accounted for debt, as if we were accounted for IFRS '16. We offer a wide of services include in order to strengthen our long-term relationships with our clients.
Slide 25, you can see here how we think about cash generation from recent acquisitions. The cash flow ratio from EBITDA recurring free cash flow is about 60%, and are expected to generate EUR 103 million on a pro forma 2-year basis around 26% of the recurring levered free cash flow generated in 2016.
Please note that all these estimations, especially the recurring free cash flow is after considering financial expenses or This has been achieved with an efficiency ---efficient capital structure by applying our strict investment criteria.
Moving to slide 26 in terms of financial outlook for 2017. We believe we can provide a recurring levered free cash flow at least 10% higher than in 2016, in line with consensus. Looking at the different contribution lines, it is important to highlight that our EBITDA is expected to reach between EUR 330 million and EUR 340 million, our CapEx guidance both maintenance and expansion remains unchanged and dividend payable in will increased 10% compared to 2016. recurring levered free cash flow, adjust working capital that should also the interest expense paid that should follow on what coupons. And finally, the tax payment, that should be slightly below -- slightly above our payments in 2016.
Finally, I think that is what next. We're focusing on several opportunities in Europe, both and options, while maintaining our strict investment disciplined. The next session topics that are very well covered in the slides. This is a new section that we frequently ask questions. that these questions will come across in the Q&A session. So please Mark Ordan with this will start the Q&A session.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Netherlands and the U.K. are in the first step of our development in every country. Only to remind you that we categorized, we have 3 categories or 3 steps on our market development. The first one is an interaction on every country where do we always iden
componenttext:
Netherlands and the U.K. are in the first step of our development in every country. Only to remind you that we categorized, we have 3 categories or 3 steps on our market development. The first one is an interaction on every country where do we always identify some more opportunities relatively speaking. We're talking about hundreds of towers always, and allows us to to get direct relationship with the customers and to identify further opportunity for growth. The growth being in a scale is the second step in our market development. And the third one, while we are in the second step, we're always talking about thousands of towers approximately in the transaction. And then the third stage is where we have a nation-wide coverage or nation-wide footprint. And when we are able to approach our customers and then to should meet the commissioning programs in order to capture to maximize the efficiency on top of the organic growth.
So all-in-all means that we have identified previously, potential next steps in the Netherlands and in the U.K. As your mind, we cannot disclose our potential next steps in every single country, but no doubts about potential opportunities in the Netherlands, in the U.K. Otherwise, we didn't invest on those attractive markets.

componenttext: We'll answer your first question on the Small Cell. Okay, in relation to the deployment of small cells into the areas, you're right. There are several lets call real estate that can be used. We have already today in our with Barcelona City Hall, we have experience on running out through lights and pole lamps. And so in we are using light poles to deploy small cells. To have the cabinets is yes, another possibility, and I think is one of the new areas as well as using advertising panels, and this is, let's say, how we see our agreement with JCDecaux with this another potential real estate. Technically, there are certain characteristics that this real estate must have is that it has to have some height and cannot be just close to the floor, so you need a really 3 meters, 4 meters height in order to do the small coverage that the small cell is supposed to do. The agreement on moving to the second question, I understand if you were wondering whether the agreement we're having today, which is JCDecaux could be exported to other regions, other than first 2, absolutely is, yes. However, since we understood is first better to test in the areas where Cellnex is already having an very important footprint, we decided to do this first commercial agreement in those 2 countries. componenttext:
Yes, in relation to your first question on decommissioning, we're certainly now at least 25% of achievement. I think the first element here is that we are proving that decommissioning is something that is feasible totally, because this has been the question that you've been mentioning as well, but this is not, it is possible and we are actually doing. The reality is and this is also true that it has taken a little bit more time on the preparation for the par of decommissioning with the quite detailed analysis of their towers, the operators towers, our tower, our tower survival tower, how to move the fiber in the fiber so it is very detailed technical analysis that has to be performed before moving ahead with the decision of the commissioning
And second part of this question was whether if the remaining 75% we intend to shift with only one operator?  Yes is it is going to be spread among different M&A and different countries.

On the towers where there are 2 MNOs already having sharing agreements like Bouygues and JCDecaux. This is fully taken into consideration on the transactions. And this is the first transaction in Bouygues for that topology of that towers. And also in these as a second, I think very important point, in this transaction, we always kept the all or not renewal clause, which is something that makes quite, let's say a strong any risk of losing any sites, any -- at any moment because there is a redundancy of sites and I think, the the impact of that, that is what is running on in Italy that we have not been effected by payment.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hi, good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, and I'm the Head of Investor Relations at Cellnex. I would like to thank you for joining us today for our Full Year Results Conference Call. I'm joined today by Tobías Martinez, CEO; and José Manue
componenttext:
Hi, good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, and I'm the Head of Investor Relations at Cellnex. I would like to thank you for joining us today for our Full Year Results Conference Call. 
I'm joined today by Tobías Martinez, CEO; and José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director. They will lead today's presentation. We have, earlier today, posted our presentation which we will refer to throughout our prepared remarks, and then we'll open the line for a Q&A session. 
So now I hand over to Tobías Martinez. Mr. Tobías.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones for the period on Slide #4.We have again posted a solid set of results based on 4 pillars. Number one, our recurrent lever
componenttext:
Well, Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones for the period on Slide #4.
We have again posted a solid set of results based on 4 pillars. Number one, our recurrent leverage free cash flow has increased by more than 60% since our IPO, May 2015. Second, we have generated organic growth ahead of our guidance. Third, our business profile has dramatically improved as a result of the development of our European platform. And last, we continue to have a robust balance sheet with flexibility to continue capturing new growth opportunities.
On Slide #5, you can see the stronger performance of our key value metrics, with an adjusted EBITDA growing at 23% per year and a recurrent leverage free cash flow per share growing at around 30% per year during the last couple of years.
Moving to Slide #6. Here, it's important to highlight that at the beginning of 2016, we guided to 3% to 4% organic growth and we came in ahead of that guidance, which show this -- of our current operations. Including the change of perimeter during 2016, total PoPs have increased by 19% and our consolidated customer ratio by 6%. Additionally, DAS nodes have increased 13%, and we expect this new activity to become a meaningful contributor to Cellnex Telecom infrastructure service going forward. 
In terms of organic growth drivers, you can see on the Slide #7, our view for new organic PoPs as well as the progress of our decommissioning and build-to-suit program. New PoPs from multi-tenancy are expected to be generated at a similar rate as the guidance provided last year. Our decommissioning program shows 25% progress, including agreements or redesign, and a 73% progress for our build-to-suit program, including our last transaction with Bouygues Telecom in January 2017.
And additionally, our efficiency program, I can say you that it is on track. We have recently signed a commercial partnership sheet agreement with JCDecaux to strengthen our position in the DAS small cell business. And the CFO will later provide you more details on both work streams.
Moving to Slide #8, I would like to emphasize that as a result of our recent deals, we have dramatically improved our business risk profile by diversifying both in terms of geographies and exposure to new, high-quality customers. It is also worth mentioning that pro forma basis, it means including the full year affect of our deals announced in 2016 and 2017 in France, 62% of our revenues will be generated by Telecom Infrastructure Services and that our current backlog represents today 14 years of revenues or 8x our net debt.
On Slide #9, you can see the result of our geographical diversification efforts, with around half of our adjusted EBITDA to be generated outside of Spain, again, on a pro forma basis. While Cellnex has become a key player in terms of number of towers worldwide, our efforts to create a European platform translate into the map on the right-hand side, with the last example being the agreement we've recently reached with Bouygues Telecom. 
Let me please take the opportunity of summarize on Slide #10, the key characteristics of our last project in France. First of all, let me highlight the high quality of the assets; second one, the high visibility of the revenues; third, the new -- a new paradigm created in the tower industry by shifting from the classic master lease agreement to an innovative master service agreement; fourth, our tax-efficient structure; the fifth, efficient cash flows -- outflows  sorry, providing financial flexibility; and sixth, the validation of our disciplined international expansion strategy. On a run-rate basis, when all sites have been transferred and build by 2022, we are expecting an EBITDA contribution of EUR 61 million per year.
I will not go through the details on Slide #11, but I would highlight at least 4 key ideas. First, thanks to this deal, we are becoming the second-largest independent tower operator in France, gaining a scale from our first investment in September 2016. Second, increasing our presence in a highly dynamic market, as it is France. The third, the effectiveness of our portfolio offers high-quality organic growth potential. And forth, we're acquiring assets in areas with very high barriers to entry, around 24, 36 month to build new site in the main cities of France.
Moving to Slide #12, just a few words on our strong balance sheet with headroom to continue pursuing accretive M&A. We have close to EUR 2 billion in cash and available debt, our long-term and fixed capital structure in place at attractive terms and full flexibility that will allow us to optimize available funding alternatives. We will remain disciplined and stick to our criteria. There are ample opportunities available. And as we have demonstrate with recent opportunities, we will not overpay. 
Before moving to José Manuel's section, let me please highlight in Slide #13 that today, we are presenting again a solid set of results. We are posting strong organic growth and progress on our additional value-enhancing initiatives. We are taking the first step to be come a European leader in the DAS and small cells sector. We are creating a European platform, executing value-accretive acquisitions that improve our business profile. We have a robust capital structure in place. Enough firepower is still available to continue growing while optimizing funding alternatives. We continue to pursue growth opportunities with discipline and with a selective M&A approach. We are successfully integrating our recent portfolios into Cellnex. And Cellnex is today recognized as the player best positioned to consolidate the European tower landscape.
Now please allow me to hand over to José Manuel Aisa, our CFO and M&A Director, who will go through our 2016 business and financial performance. So please, José Manuel.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tobías. Good afternoon. As a reminder, please note that additional information can be obtained on the Investor Relations sections of our website, where there is a detailed express [ph] file and should we also the annuals accounts of the compan
componenttext:
Thank you, Tobías. Good afternoon. As a reminder, please note that additional information can be obtained on the Investor Relations sections of our website, where there is a detailed express [ph] file and should we also the annuals accounts of the company.
So if now we go to slide 15, you can see here the evolution of PoPs and our consolidated tenancy ratio, with increases mainly explained by consistent organic growth and change of perimeter. We have managed to add more than 900 dynamic [ph] PoPs in the period, reaching a tenancy ratio of 1.62, including M&A. 
Additionally, we are pursuing new organic growth opportunities in all business areas with a special mention to framework agreements with mobile operators, entering new markets, decommissioning and build-to-suit projects and other recent agreements with JCDecaux to strengthen our position in the small cells market. 
This balance sheet applies when opportunity arise in Spain and Italy for initial period of 18 months in venue current JCDecaux presence or when a new tender process is launched to manage advertising sites, and is based on a preferred partner, relying on JCDecaux's exiting capabilities and adding on top of that our own capabilities to increase the value position.
Moving to slide 16, you can see here the progress of our efficiency plan. As anticipated last year, the main contributor to this program is our site management project, with around 30% of the targeted savings already achieved. We have devoted CapEx of EUR 31 million between cash advance and land acquisition with paybacks of 5 years and average saving around lease, about 20%, with a resulting contract length beyond 15 years. We're also making good progress on our additional initiatives with around 50% of the targeted savings already achieved. Our ultimate objective for the efficiency plan will be for savings to offset higher future cost due to a pricing and increased operating activity so we can show a flat OpEx performance on a like-for-like basis going forward.
On the next slide, you can find a [indiscernible] explanation of our adjusted EBITDA evolution. You can see how the negative impact of the DTT simulcast in 2015 is more than offset by the switch on of the new TV channels, together with organic growth contribution and change of perimeter, explaining the strong adjusted EBITDA increase in the year of 23%, in other words, EUR 290 million of adjusted EBITDA.
If we now focus on the adjusted EBITDA margin evolution on the next slide, operating leverage coming from organic growth increases our margin by 1%, broadcasting by additional 2%. And if we adjust for pass-through cost and revenues, we end up with an adjusted EBITDA margin of 43%.
Slide 19. We will now focus on our capital allocation for the year. We have devoted 90% of our total investment to M&A with 8% allocated to expansion CapEx. We deploy organic growth CapEx with a strict return criteria of low teens unlevered IRR. And as you can see, the majority has been dedicated in 2016 to our efficiency plan.
Slide 20, regarding capital structure. Our debt maturities profile as of February 2016 presents the first maturity -- or an average maturity of around 7 years, with no material refinancing required before 2022, and protection against potential interest rates hikes due to the fixed cost nature of our debt.
Slide 21. There, we provide an updated snapshot of our capital structure after our last bond issue in January. We have a long-term capital structure in place at attractive terms, with EUR 1.8 billion of liquidity between cash and available credit lines.
Let me now explain on slide 22, our recurring levered free cash flow generation in the period. I would like to start by highlighting that the cash conversion ratio of EBITDA into recurring levered free cash flow in the period has been a strong 87%, with the total figure increasing 30% when compared to the recurrent levered free cash flow of 2015.
Looking now to revenues. The contribution from all the different businesses line increase with our very well-contained cost base, leading to an adjusted EBITDA growth of 23% when compared to last year. Maintenance CapEx is in line with our guidance of 3% of revenues. And our change in working capital is positive due to a one-off revenue collection measures, but expected to be neutral going forward, in line with our guidance. Interest rates reflects our capital structure as of December, with coupons already paid in Q3 and taxes reflecting the implementation of tax management measures. 
All-in-all, we are posting a 15% revenue growth, which implies almost doubling our recurrent levered free cash flow growth when compared to last year.
Moving now to our balance sheet on slide 23. Cellnex leverage for the period has reached 4.6x net debt annualized EBITDA after investing more than EUR 700 million in the year. Our balance sheet reflects the increase in fixed assets due to our recent acquisitions. Recurrent net profit, adjusted for one-off noncash task tax effect last year, increases to 38%. And net interest increased mainly due to accrued cost in the year.
On shareholder remuneration, we will pay EUR 22 million in 2017, a 10% increase over the dividend paid in 2016.
Moving to M&A activity in 2015 -- '16, sorry. On slide 24, we explain what we believe is a new paradigm in the tower industry: Our ability to create master service agreement with our clients from scratch, making sure these services were not be accounted for debt, as -- if it were accounted following IFRS 16. We offer a wide array of services beyond pure real estate in order to strengthen our long-term relationships with our clients.
Slide 25, you can see here how we think about cash flow generation from recent acquisitions. The cash conversion ratio from EBITDA into recurrent levered free cash flow is above 60%, and the new deals are expected to generate EUR 103 million on a pro forma full year basis, around 26% of the recurrent levered free cash flow generated in 2016. Please note that all these estimations, especially the recurrent levered free cash flow, is after considering financial expenses borne by Cellnex. 
And all this has been achieved with an efficiency -- efficient and flexible capital structure and by applying our strict investment criteria.
Moving to slide 26 in terms of financial outlook for 2017. We believe we can provide a recurrent levered free cash flow at least 10% higher than in 2016, in line with consensus. Looking at the different contribution lines, it is important to highlight that our adjusted EBITDA is expected to reach between EUR 330 million and EUR 340 million. Our CapEx guidance, both maintenance and expansion, remains unchanged. And dividend payable in 2017 will increased 10% compared to 2016. 
There are other things that belong to recurrent levered free cash flow, such as the working capital. That should tend to be neutral; also the interest expense paid, that should follow our coupons; and finally, the tax payment, that should be slightly below -- slightly above our payment in 2016.
Finally, knowing -- I think that is, what's next? We are focusing on several opportunities in Europe, both proprietary and auctions, while maintaining our strict investment discipline. 
The next section addresses several key topics that are very well covered in the slides. This is a new section that we have called frequently asked questions. But I think that these questions, we'll come across in the -- in your Q&A session. 
So please follow -- please -- with this, we can start the Q&A session.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Simon Coles from Barclays. I was just wondering if you could give us a few more details about the partnership that you signed with JCDecaux, and maybe some indication on how the economics are going to work on this partnership. Then my second quest
componenttext: This is Simon Coles from Barclays. I was just wondering if you could give us a few more details about the partnership that you signed with JCDecaux, and maybe some indication on how the economics are going to work on this partnership. Then my second question is around the Bouygues deal, I'm just wondering, is this the sort of structure for deals that you'd like to do in the future? In that you stagger the payment and the transfer of title if you're buying towers. Or you said that you can remain flexible with your -- on the balance sheet. And then final question, just a quick one. If you had any guidance for midterm outlook for the Netherlands and U.K. I know they're very stable businesses and very cash generative. I just wondered if you have any thoughts on that.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, first on the JCDecaux answer. This is Alex Mestre, Chief Commercial Officer. This agreement certainly has been signed recently. It is a sort of an agreement that we are both parties trying to have a common approach to the market. We've been try
componenttext: Yes. Well, first on the JCDecaux answer. This is Alex Mestre, Chief Commercial Officer. This agreement certainly has been signed recently. It is a sort of an agreement that we are both parties trying to have a common approach to the market. We've been trying to deal with small cells as a initial deployment for this new market. And both together, we believe we can add jointly a set of tools together that can speed up a little bit the deployment of this market. Our budget is not being influenced by this agreement so far, and we need to see yet the go-to-market on the 2 countries where we are initially having these commercial agreement in both sides. And we intend to at least continue with the growth on DAS and the small cells. We categorize both product lines into a single one, which is what we call densification of macro sides into smaller sites. And here, we can attack the market with 2 products: DAS, which is distributed antenna systems; or small cells. We've reached 13% growth during 2016 and we expect that we should be able, of course, to follow the same growth we've been achieving so far. And taking into account, there is on page 31, an assumption on how we understand the market will grow from 2018 onwards up to 2025, where the analysts are projecting a CAGR of roughly 20% per year. So that's the intended approach onto that market, both parties together. There are 3 slides devoted on the appendix -- 4 slides actually, from the slide 30 to slide 33, which are focusing all the different topologies of deployment for densification. And there is one as well related to the JCDecaux.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first question Simon, you were asking about the structure of the Bouygues deal, if that is something that we would want to replicate going forward? [indiscernible].
componenttext: Yes. So first question Simon, you were asking about the structure of the Bouygues deal, if that is something that we would want to replicate going forward? [indiscernible].

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: So yes, I think that the Bouygues deal represents the -- a good example of what we will like to implement in the next deals. First of all, it's a deal that is coming from an MNO, so directly from the client. And this is really important in which we can de
componenttext: So yes, I think that the Bouygues deal represents the -- a good example of what we will like to implement in the next deals. First of all, it's a deal that is coming from an MNO, so directly from the client. And this is really important in which we can develop our competitive advantage. And if you ask me, which is the competitive advantage of Cellnex compared to other players, I will say is to be able to sit down with a client and to draft from a scratch a new MSA. And a new MSA, which is no longer a MLA. We have evolved here in towering in Europe, allow us to step-by-step be in the front and to develop new [indiscernible] understand the needs of our clients to meet these needs and to create value in the long term for both. These are win-win agreements. So yes, this is a new paradigm that meets not only the requirements in terms of technical aspects, but also from accountancy aspects, as this is no longer IFRS 16 lease, but as a pure service, as pure infrastructure to service as you can find in other sectors.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: There was a last question on opportunities in the Netherlands and the U.K.
componenttext: There was a last question on opportunities in the Netherlands and the U.K.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Oh, the Netherlands and the U.K. are in the first step of our development in every country. Only to remind you that we categorized -- we have 3 categories or 3 steps on our market development. The first one is an interaction on every country where do we a
componenttext: Oh, the Netherlands and the U.K. are in the first step of our development in every country. Only to remind you that we categorized -- we have 3 categories or 3 steps on our market development. The first one is an interaction on every country where do we always identify small opportunities, relatively speaking, we are talking about hundreds of towers always, and allows us to get direct relationship with the customers and to identify further opportunity for growth. The growth gaining scale is the second step in our market development. And the third one, while we are in the second step, we're always talking about thousand of towers approximately in the transaction. And then the third stage is where we have a nationwide coverage or nationwide footprint. And when we are able to approach our customers and then to -- should meet decommissioning programs in order to capture to maximize the efficiency on top of the organic growth. So all-in-all, means that we have identified previously, potential next steps in the Netherlands and in the U.K. As you can imagine, we cannot disclose our potential next steps in every single country, but no doubts about potential opportunities in the Netherlands, in the U.K. Otherwise, we didn't invest on those attractive markets.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Giles Thorne from Dan (sic).
componenttext: Your next question comes from Giles Thorne from Dan (sic).

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have 3 questions, please. This is Giles Thorne here from Jefferies. The first one was on Italy, and specifically, Fastweb has spoken about a small cell deployment in that country in the 3.5 gigahertz spectrum range that it acquired with Tiscali last yea
componenttext: I have 3 questions, please. This is Giles Thorne here from Jefferies. The first one was on Italy, and specifically, Fastweb has spoken about a small cell deployment in that country in the 3.5 gigahertz spectrum range that it acquired with Tiscali last year. And now they've spoken about actually using their proprietary cabinet footprint in Italy for the small cell deployment. But it would be interesting to know if there will be any opportunity for Cellnex to support that. Or do you think Fastweb will rely solely on their own infrastructure? And the second question that kind of leads on from that. And that the -- and it's also another question about the JCDecaux commercial alliance. Now small cell deployments comes with many challenges and not least is getting access to the ground level street furniture. We've seen with Fastweb, they'll try and use their own cabinets. So when it comes to the JCDecaux commercial alliance, it seems like you've got a fantastic opportunity to get access to And that ground infrastructure. Now it's just Spain initially at the moment, but should we expect to see the geographic scope of that commercial alliance expanded? And also, will that commercial alliance sit with the Commscon management team? And so a question there on JCDecaux. And then lastly, on the Bouygues deal, and you've touched on this already, but it does feel like a bellwether for European outsourcing. It's amongst a very few MNO sale and leaseback deals that haven't been driven by leverage pressures at the MNO. It'd be interesting to know how you found working with the Bouygues management team and compare that to other management teams at other MNOs. And also, any sense that there are discussions for expanding that agreement? Are you doing more sale and leasebacks in France?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Alex will answer your first questions from the small cells.
componenttext: Alex will answer your first questions from the small cells.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, in relation to deployment of small cells into the dense urban areas, you are right. There are several, let's call it, urban real estate that can be used. We have already today in our existing contract with Barcelona City Hall, we have experience on
componenttext: Okay, in relation to deployment of small cells into the dense urban areas, you are right. There are several, let's call it, urban real estate that can be used. We have already today in our existing contract with Barcelona City Hall, we have experience on running out through traffic lights and pole lamps. Also in Milano, we are using light poles to deploy small cells. To have the cabinets is, yes, another possibility, and I think is one of the new areas, as well as using advertising panels. And this is, let's say, how we see our agreement with JCDecaux, which is another potential real estate. Technically, there are certain characteristics that this [indiscernible] real estate must have, is that it has to have some height, cannot be just close to the floor. So you need ideally 3 meters, 4 meters height in order to do the small coverage that the small cell is supposed to do. The agreement on -- moving to the second question, I understand if you were wondering whether the agreement we are having today with JCDecaux could be exported to other regions other than the first 2. Absolutely yes. However, since we understood is first better to test in the areas where Cellnex is already having a very important footprint, we decided to do this first commercial agreement in those 2 countries. And in relation to third questions, I may start, and Tobias, you may follow. the point is...

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The relationship with the Bouygues management. I understand, no?
componenttext: The relationship with the Bouygues management. I understand, no?

componenttext: I understood.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. So it seems to me the Bouygues management has shown a very progressive mentality towards passive infrastructure, more progressive than any other operator who didn't have leverage constraints. So it'd be interesting to know how your expe
componenttext: Yes, that's right. So it seems to me the Bouygues management has shown a very progressive mentality towards passive infrastructure, more progressive than any other operator who didn't have leverage constraints. So it'd be interesting to know how your experience differed with the type of conversations you're having with other operators.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: No, thank you. This is a very good example of our strategy. As José Manuel said before, for us, is very, very, very different when we transact with customer rather than other players in the market. I mean, to develop the customer relationship is key for
componenttext: No, thank you. This is a very good example of our strategy. As José Manuel said before, for us, is very, very, very different when we transact with customer rather than other players in the market. I mean, to develop the customer relationship is key for us. If you remember our first transaction with Bouygues was in September. And only, let me say only. I'll remark. Only after 4 months, we, together with the Bouygues management team, and as we have been able to reach an agreement on thousand of assets and a very high quality of assets. So very sensitive transaction for both parties. And this is the reason why I fully agree with you. Management of Bouygues, I think, it's very positive, is very open to consider maybe even a full outsourcing on the existing infrastructures. Well -- and not only on the existing infrastructure story, because we had reached a very important build-to-suit program of 1,200 new infrastructure.

componenttext: Well, we tried to do the same with all our customers, no doubt about that. Not only with Bouygues, you are right. But this is our, let me say, commercial approach.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had a few questions as well. Firstly in terms of your decommissioning schedules, so the 2,000 sites, you're saying 25% is in progress. What does that actually mean? Does not mean we could expect that to happen in 2017 and it's sort of already included i
componenttext: I had a few questions as well. Firstly in terms of your decommissioning schedules, so the 2,000 sites, you're saying 25% is in progress. What does that actually mean? Does not mean we could expect that to happen in 2017 and it's sort of already included in your guidance? And then on the same topic, so the remaining 75%, is that with the same operator as -- or operators as the first 75% -- or 25%? And then I guess a little but more generally, you got quite a few growth opportunities going on. You're looking at new markets, you're doing small cells and DAS and you're consolidating your existing markets. If you sort of, I guess, firstly prioritize, what is it you're working most with? And then I guess maybe that's the same order, but which of these options are you -- or opportunities are you the most excited about and think will contribute the most if we look a couple of years out? I think that's it.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, in relation to your first question on decommissioning, yes, certainly now, we are on least 25% of achievement. I think the first relevant element here is that we are proving that decommissioning is something that is feasible totally, no? because this
componenttext: Yes, in relation to your first question on decommissioning, yes, certainly now, we are on least 25% of achievement. I think the first relevant element here is that we are proving that decommissioning is something that is feasible totally, no? because this has been repeatedly a question that you've been mentioning as well. But this is not -- well, it is possible and we are actually doing. The reality is, and this is also true, that it has taken a little bit more time on the preparation for the plans of decommissioning with this quite detailed analysis of pairs of towers, the operator's towers, our tower, define which is the survivor tower, how to move the fiber if the fiber is there. So it is very detailed technical analysis that has to be performed before moving ahead with the decision of decommissioning a tower. I think the second part of this question was whether if the remaining 75%, we intend to shift with only one operator or several.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, the idea is, as we can -- we said earlier, we are currently in 5 countries, but we are in different stage of market development. So we want to develop, in every single country, our strategy in order to gain in scale for growth and to be able for con
componenttext: Well, the idea is, as we can -- we said earlier, we are currently in 5 countries, but we are in different stage of market development. So we want to develop, in every single country, our strategy in order to gain in scale for growth and to be able for consolidation. This is our first priority. Second one, focus remain our target. I mean, we are looking for opportunities in Europe. Sometimes, the opportunities will come because -- as a public tender, as a competitive process. But the company, it's working always very proactively, approaching customers in identifying opportunities. And then, let me say, to create or to define new opportunities in our bilateral discussions. Obviously, I cannot disclose in which and where we are working, but well, we have a very attractive pipeline of opportunities in Europe. And we will disclose them in -- when we execute or when we can disclose.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Can I just follow up, actually? So on the first question, sort of 25% that you say is in progress, do you expect to have that done this year? Or is it more sort of it's in progress, and it will be over the next few years or couple of years? And then actua
componenttext: Can I just follow up, actually? So on the first question, sort of 25% that you say is in progress, do you expect to have that done this year? Or is it more sort of it's in progress, and it will be over the next few years or couple of years? And then actually on the pipeline as well, I mean, is it more skewed towards your existing markets or new markets, would you say?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: For us, the 25% means fully contracted decommissioning projects. That's the concept of this 25%. And yes, normally, it should be in process of decommissioning to be fully achieved, over within the 2017 year.
componenttext: For us, the 25% means fully contracted decommissioning projects. That's the concept of this 25%. And yes, normally, it should be in process of decommissioning to be fully achieved, over within the 2017 year.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

componenttext: And the second question, our main priority is to consolidate our positioning on the existing markets. But it doesn't means that we cannot analyze or to approach other opportunities in Europe.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions from me on the PoP growth, organic PoP growth. You achieved 4.5% in 2016, which is better than your guidance. Do you expect to achieve this growth rate again this year? And then again on the PoP growth, the 3%, 4% over 2016, 2019, I assum
componenttext: Just 2 questions from me on the PoP growth, organic PoP growth. You achieved 4.5% in 2016, which is better than your guidance. Do you expect to achieve this growth rate again this year? And then again on the PoP growth, the 3%, 4% over 2016, 2019, I assume this is an average overall all, countries, but do you expect to see a lot of differences in terms of growth per country?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Charles, on the guidance for PoP provided [indiscernible], basically, what -- we want consistent with the guidance we provided at the beginning of the year. It is true that we have been ahead of our guidance in terms of organic growth for this year. Mostl
componenttext: Charles, on the guidance for PoP provided [indiscernible], basically, what -- we want consistent with the guidance we provided at the beginning of the year. It is true that we have been ahead of our guidance in terms of organic growth for this year. Mostly look at Q3, there was quite a high activity. In any case, even the landing [ph] profile of how we attract new PoPs every quarter, I think it's important for us to provide exactly as can be for in the long term. So that is why we're keeping this 3%, 4% guidance in the medium term. With any more information we get from our customers, we might be adjusting that. But this is the result of information we have today and data we feel comfortable with. In terms of organic growth being generated by different countries, exactly the same as you have seen in 2016. The profile will be consistent, countries are providing similar levels of organic growth. So obviously with slight differences. For example, in Netherlands, you know that, that tenancy rate is already quite high. But on the previous markets, we are expecting a stabilizing, as seen in 2016.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

componenttext: The next question comes from Ottavio Adorisio from Societe Generale.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have 3 question, if I may. The first one is on JCDecaux. I have to be honest, I was bit surprised in that one because, basically in 2014, Vodafone did sign a similar agreement with them. It's a worldwide agreement, it's a 15-year contract and it's almos
componenttext:
I have 3 question, if I may. The first one is on JCDecaux. I have to be honest, I was bit surprised in that one because, basically in 2014, Vodafone did sign a similar agreement with them. It's a worldwide agreement, it's a 15-year contract and it's almost the same sort of content of the agreements you signed yourself.
So I would like to, if possible, for you to give some color, how it's going to work between the 3 of you, is Vodafone going to have access to the same sites that you're going to use? And you're going to have an overlapping of different sites, and so on and so forth? The second one is on Italy. I've seen that you're recording pretty good growth on PoPs. Now it's no secret anymore WIND and Hutchinson are basically merging. WIND is basically honoring the contract. And therefore, it's very likely that the Hutchinson tender will be moving at some stage. So I was wondering, if anything -- any movements on that side, I've seen that the growth in Italy is relatively robust, especially when compared to Spain. And I was wondering who are the PoPs that are actually moving towards your towers? The third, it's a followup from previous answer to JCDecaux again. I was talking about the fact that the budget for the JCDecaux has not been formulated or places have not been finalized. So I was wondering is that means that the free cash flow guidance you provide today, it's gross of any investments you have to make on that particular agreement? Or it's basically already been accounted on your free cash flow guidance?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. In relation to your first question, honestly, we do not know the details on all that potential agreement that our partner may be having. The truth is that, at any moment, we've been having any kind of restriction on rolling out the go-to-market of t
componenttext: Okay. In relation to your first question, honestly, we do not know the details on all that potential agreement that our partner may be having. The truth is that, at any moment, we've been having any kind of restriction on rolling out the go-to-market of the agreement, which is only commercial, going to your last point, but it is on the commercial agreement on those 2 markets. So, sofar we do not foresee any restriction with any MNO on deploying this agreement in Spain and Italy. The second question was, actually in Italy -- the growth in Italy, no? So growth in Italy has several factors. I think we've been also press releasing some agreement we've been having with one, let's say, broadband operator in Italy. This is one of the elements, also one of our several decommissioning projects is in Italy, which in turn brings also additional point of presence. And that's basically the main elements about, let's say, the regular growth that has been guided into this presentation that we're having in Italy.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And regarding the third question, Ottavio, we have presented to you what we think is our proven approach to 2017. And I think everything is embedded there, okay? If during the year, our view has to be updated, we will share with you as we have done, but s
componenttext: And regarding the third question, Ottavio, we have presented to you what we think is our proven approach to 2017. And I think everything is embedded there, okay? If during the year, our view has to be updated, we will share with you as we have done, but so far, this is our best estimation.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Fernando Cordero from Banco Santander.
componenttext: The next question comes from Fernando Cordero from Banco Santander.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The first one is just a follow-up on the 2017 guidance and also understanding [indiscernible] how to say, way of presenting the guidance, I just would like to check if the building blocks exercise for this guidance is as we're going to foreseeing the EUR
componenttext: The first one is just a follow-up on the 2017 guidance and also understanding [indiscernible] how to say, way of presenting the guidance, I just would like to check if the building blocks exercise for this guidance is as we're going to foreseeing the EUR 275 million organic or -- sorry, EUR 279 million and EBITDA for 2016 plus the EUR 38 million, EUR 39 million EBITDA coming from a change of perimeter during the year 2016, it implies that the guidance is assuming that the organic growth is going to be between [indiscernible] 4% of the EBITDA growth and in this organic growth [indiscernible] just would like to check the math and at which extent this organic growth is quite conservative? My second question is the expansion of CapEx, the organic expansion of CapEx, and particularly on the effort that you have made during 2016 on efficiencies and particularly on ground leases. In that sense, I just would like to know first, at which extent have you been buying land, not just renegotiating the ground leases contract? And to what extent should we expect the same activity or the same CapEx for the next couple of years? And finally, on the dividend, although you just were clear that Cellnex is not focusing on dividend, I would like just to, I will say, to know if you are changing your dividend policy as you are guiding for 10% growth in dividend for 2017? Or is it just, I'm going to say, did arrive from the fact that your recurrent levered free cash flow just got below 10%, so 20% of this free cash flow volume is just growing 10%. Or in other words, what could -- what should be the dividend policy going forward, 10% growth per year or 20% of the peak cash flow?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The first question is, it's about your estimates on our guidance we gave to you. Listen, there is -- regarding the Bouygues deal, we do think that in 2017, the impact of Bouygues deal on the EBITDA should be rather limited, okay. So when doing your estima
componenttext: The first question is, it's about your estimates on our guidance we gave to you. Listen, there is -- regarding the Bouygues deal, we do think that in 2017, the impact of Bouygues deal on the EBITDA should be rather limited, okay. So when doing your estimation, please factor into the equation this that being conservative or not will depend also on a change of perimeter of the impact of this leading to the -- into that position, okay. So regarding your second question, which is about the expansion of CapEx. You're right. We have, I think we have been quite happy with this program. Most of the program, cash from renegotiation and cash advances done ground-lease acquisitions, okay. So this is something that is important to say. And very specially, when to say it was going on in the next years, you can see that this EUR 57 million represents 7.5% of the total revenues, which is within our guidance between 5% and 10% of revenues diverted to expansion CapEx. I do think we will follow this guidance. So step-by-step, I think that we will be able to increase further the ground lease renegotiation program, which is very interesting. And finally, regarding your dividend statement, we -- let me say to you that this dividend -- this dividend suggestion, this dividend payment in 2017, '18, '19, it's a crystallization of our dividend policy. If you know that at 20% recurrent levered free cash flow had to be commensurate with also the growth of the company, the net income of the company. So we do think that this is crystallization for 3 years that in quantity of money that makes sense with all the patterns that we commensurate this 20% recurrent levered free cash flow. So our dividend policy was a little bit maybe more developed than what you say. I think that's all, Fernando, thank you very much.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

componenttext: Just, if I may, a followup question on the ground leases and given your current experience, what you are finding the most interesting, I'm going to say, financial profile of the ground lease renegotiation, renegotiating, buying the land?

componenttext: I would say to you that renegotiating -- renegotiating, first, cash advances and buying land. This will be the order.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sorry, just to clarify, Fernando, we've seen that cash advances is a very powerful tool. I would say that this is representing maybe the savings we are seeing today are mostly coming from this. Buying land is something we are starting to do, but going for
componenttext: Sorry, just to clarify, Fernando, we've seen that cash advances is a very powerful tool. I would say that this is representing maybe the savings we are seeing today are mostly coming from this. Buying land is something we are starting to do, but going forward, that could be also a very powerful weapon to take into consideration.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Parin Shah from Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question comes from Parin Shah from Bank of America.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's Parin Shah from Bank of America. I've got 3 questions. The first one is, so in the U.K., I guess, there is enough available that are of significant scale, but it would also mean dialing back the progress you've been making in reducing the broadcast e
componenttext: It's Parin Shah from Bank of America. I've got 3 questions. The first one is, so in the U.K., I guess, there is enough available that are of significant scale, but it would also mean dialing back the progress you've been making in reducing the broadcast exposure in your portfolio. So would you tolerate, I guess, bidding for this asset and would cement great scale on a big 5 European market or it is something you wouldn't really consider because of the progress you made on broadcast in reducing that exposure? Question two, so the Bouygues tower deal, I think that's a bit appreciated, it's quite an interesting deal. I was just wondering whether you could confirm the sale process was conducted on an exclusive basis with Cellnex being the only bidder. And I was wondering whether you are confident that you can carry on doing this in future negotiations, essentially wondering why wouldn't operator not choose to conduct discussions with multiple parties, including American Tower. And just on that, did that provide support for you pulling out of an FPS deal where otherwise you would be bidding at quite an elevated multiple. And question 3, on your growth guidance. I guess, there could be a material step change in growth in some of your geographies, particularly in Italy, if -- and depending on when the 4th operator choose to build. Would you consider such growth to be incremental to your 3% to 4% guidance? And those are the questions.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, many questions. I don't -- let's see if I'm able to answer all of them. Otherwise, you help me to remind because there has been quite a set of questions. Well, your first question was talking about [indiscernible] and any other investment in the las
componenttext: Well, many questions. I don't -- let's see if I'm able to answer all of them. Otherwise, you help me to remind because there has been quite a set of questions. Well, your first question was talking about [indiscernible] and any other investment in the last case for Cellnex has to comply our strict M&A criteria. And this is very important. I mean, it's not -- I'm very sorry, we'll not be [indiscernible] or nothing else. Just to remind very quickly, our M&A criteria is low double-digit in terms of equity IRR. Second, improvement of our cash flow visibility of business risk profile. And finally, the accretive impact on our recurrent free cash flow per share from year 2 onwards. So it's quite strict and this criteria and just to answer another question you were saying, regarding FPS, was your fourth question, I think. You said to ask that obviously, this opportunity did not meet our criteria. So I'm very sorry. All that will come. It could not happen our criteria. So when talking about American Tower, which is your third question, I think, American Tower has always been there. It's not the first time it has been in Europe, back in 2011, it was competing with us with all their towers, with our first tower in Spain. So it has always been there. And our competitor advantage is not only debt from payment, it is as we said before in other question -- the answer is to be able to sit down with a client to build up a new MSA contract to understand their needs. That's really important. And your second question was about Bouygues -- Bouygues? The process was a competitive process. Of course, it was a competitive process. Maybe it was not in the press everyday, but it was competitive. And if we were able to win, it's because we were able to do a unique offer. An unique offer from many angles, not only the upfront payment, but also our capacity to understand their needs today and tomorrow. And in order to do so, you need credentials. You need industrial angle, you need partnership in the long term and this make us unique in comparison with others. And finally, you're talking about, I think it was growth and MNO [indiscernible] should have an impact in 2018, not before. We've been consistent with this message. So what the guidance we have represented to you is consistent.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sorry. I was on mute. The first one is on the Bouygues deal. And I was wondering if you can -- if you are able to may be to share some color of -- about the deal maybe from the mobile network operators perspective, and particularly with regards to the tre
componenttext: Sorry. I was on mute. The first one is on the Bouygues deal. And I was wondering if you can -- if you are able to may be to share some color of -- about the deal maybe from the mobile network operators perspective, and particularly with regards to the treatment in the IFRS '16 empowerment. So the service agreement that you have, will Bouygues have to basically reported as part of long-term lease in their net debt definition? Or does it stay out of the net debt with IFRS '16 new rules? The second question is on cross-border synergies. I mean, traditionally other tower companies have always stated there are no synergies. I see you have a slide in your presentation making the case for it. If you can probably a bit elaborate on your views on that, I think you are in better position than others in Europe to comment on that? And thirdly, just to go back on the dividend guidance and dividend outlook. So if I understand well, your numbers, effectively, we are talking about EUR 0.091 of DPS in 2016, which can become EUR 0.10 in 2017. Now consensus on Bloomberg for '17 is about EUR 0.21. So are we getting this right that you are well below consensus on your new dividend outlook?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, many questions, Luigi. Let's see. First was about IFRS '16. We -- I don't know how different our [indiscernible] it is from country's perspective. What I can tell you is that we are working on MSAs, not longer in MLAs, which means that IFRS '16 defi
componenttext: Well, many questions, Luigi. Let's see. First was about IFRS '16. We -- I don't know how different our [indiscernible] it is from country's perspective. What I can tell you is that we are working on MSAs, not longer in MLAs, which means that IFRS '16 defines very well what is a lease and what is not a lease. And therefore, if anyone understands the criteria and takes our contract, will categorize this contract as an MSA and therefore -- under IFRS '15. But this is the treatment -- the accountancy treatment depends on the different parties. Regarding the cross-border synergies on page 34, the only intention of Page 34 is to tell you that when talking about cross borders, you have to look at the countries, yes, so the clients. At the end of the day, if our great advantage is to sit down and develop a new contract with our client and therefore, if you have already a common way of communication with this client, this can be somehow repetitive knowledge. That's very important. So towering is our client, not about towers only, okay? You were talking also about.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: What? On the dividend.
componenttext: What? On the dividend.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The dividend, yes, and this is also that Fernando raised the point and obviously, the market consensus would say, dividends were following the 20% recurrent levered free cash flow. And now we're saying to you that we crystallize this 20% recurrent levered
componenttext: The dividend, yes, and this is also that Fernando raised the point and obviously, the market consensus would say, dividends were following the 20% recurrent levered free cash flow. And now we're saying to you that we crystallize this 20% recurrent levered free cash flow commensurate with net income M&A growth. We crystallize for 3 years 10% growth in relation to 2016 payment. And therefore, this is a new guidance and cannot match the consensual that you have in front of you. We do think it makes sense for this new 3 years to do what we'll have to, which is to create value for our shareholders.

componenttext: Let me start by the last one, the working capital adjustment, we said this is one-off because we have changed our policy in terms of how we manage -- how we manage the capacity to charge to a client. componenttext: Yes, on consolidation, well, as you can assume, we've been exposing other transactions through long time foreseeing mergers that finally happen, so we've been having quite a lot of time to identify them and protect ourselves on those. Please allow me not be very explicit, but in the case of France, I think there are 2 elements: one, is the initial tenant surety for all those towers is quite low. On the towers where there are 2 MNOs already having -- sharing agreements like Bouygues [indiscernible] this is fully taken into consideration on the transactions. And this is the first transaction in Bouygues for the typology of the towers. And also in this, as a second, I think very important point in this transactions, we always kept all or not in renewal clause, which is something that makes quite, let's say, strong -- any risk of losing any sites at any moment because there is a redundancy of sites and I think the proven part of that is what is weighing on in Italy that we have not been effected by payment.

componenttext: Basically Jonathan, access to all of sites is simply a concessor way of saying that they have access to all of our towers in Italy.
