headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hi, good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, and I'm the Head of Investor Relations at Cellnex. I would like to thank you for joining us today for our Full Year Results Conference Call. I'm joined today by Tobías Martinez, CEO; and José Manue
componenttext:
Hi, good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, and I'm the Head of Investor Relations at Cellnex. I would like to thank you for joining us today for our Full Year Results Conference Call. 
I'm joined today by Tobías Martinez, CEO; and José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director. They will lead today's presentation. We have, earlier today, posted our presentation which we will refer to throughout our prepared remarks, and then we'll open the line for a Q&A session. 
So now I hand over to Tobías Martinez. Mr. Tobías.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones for the period on Slide #4.We have again posted a solid set of results based on 4 pillars. Number one, our recurrent lever
componenttext:
Well, Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones for the period on Slide #4.
We have again posted a solid set of results based on 4 pillars. Number one, our recurrent leverage free cash flow has increased by more than 60% since our IPO, May 2015. Second, we have generated organic growth ahead of our guidance. Third, our business profile has dramatically improved as a result of the development of our European platform. And last, we continued to have a robust balance sheet with flexibility to continue capturing new growth opportunities.
On Slide #5, you can see the stronger performance of our key value metrics, with an adjusted EBITDA growing at 23% per year and a recurrent leverage free cash flow per share growing at around 30% per year during the last couple of years.
Moving to Slide #6. Here, it's important to highlight that at the beginning of 2016, we guided to 3% to 4% organic growth and we came in ahead of that guidance, which show this -- of our current operations. Including the change of perimeter during 2016, total PoPs have increased by 19% and our consolidated customer ratio by 6%. Additionally, DAS nodes have increased 13%, and we expect this new activity to become a meaningful contributor to Cellnex Telecom infrastructure service going forward. 
In terms of organic growth drivers, you can see on the Slide #7, our view for new organic PoPs as well as the progress of our decommissioning and build-to-suit program. New PoPs from multi-tenancy are expected to be generated at a similar rate as the guidance provided last year. Our decommissioning program shows 25% progress, including agreements or redesign, and a 73% progress for our build-to-suit program, including our last transaction with Bouygues Telecom in January 2017.
And additionally, our efficiency program, I can say you that it is on track and we have recently signed a commercial partnership sheet agreement with JCDecaux to strengthen our position in the DAS small cell business. And the CFO will later provide you more details on both work streams.
Moving to Slide #8, I would like to emphasize that as a result of our recent deals, we have dramatically improved our business risk profile by diversifying both in terms of geographies and exposure to new, high-quality customers. It is also worth mentioning that pro forma basis, it means including the full year effect of our deals announced in 2016 and 2017 in France 62% of our revenues will be generated by Telecom Infrastructure Services and that our current backlog represents today 14 years of revenues or 8x our net debt.
On Slide #9, you can see the result of our geographical diversification efforts, with around half of our adjusted EBITDA to be generated outside of Spain, again, on a pro forma basis. While Cellnex has become a key player in terms of number of towers worldwide, our efforts to create a European platform translate into the map on the right-hand side, with the last example being the agreement we've recently reached with Bouygues Telecom. 
Let me please take the opportunity of summarize on Slide #10, the key characteristics of our last project in France. First of all, let me highlight the high quality of the assets; second one, the high visibility of the revenues; third, the new -- a new paradigm created in the tower industry by shifting from the classic master lease agreement to an innovative master service agreement; fourth, our tax-efficient structure; the fifth, efficient cash flows -- outflows  sorry, providing financial flexibility; and sixth, the validation of our disciplined international expansion strategy. On a run-rate basis, when all sites have been transferred and built by 2022, we are expecting an EBITDA contribution of EUR 61 million per year.
I will not go through the details on Slide #11, but I would highlight at least 4 key ideas. First, thanks to this deal, we are becoming the second-largest independent tower operator in France, gaining a scale from our first investment in September 2016. Second, increasing our presence in a highly dynamic market, as it is France. The third, the effectiveness of our portfolio offers high-quality organic growth potential. And forth, we're acquiring assets in areas with very high barriers to entry, around 24, 36 month to build new site in the main cities of France.
Moving to Slide #12, just a few words on our strong balance sheet with headroom to continue pursuing accretive M&A. We have close to EUR 2 billion in cash and available debt, our long-term and fixed capital structure in place at attractive terms and full flexibility that will allow us to optimize available funding alternatives. We will remain disciplined and stick to our criteria. There are ample opportunities available. And as we have demonstrate with recent opportunities, we will not overpay. 
Before moving to José Manuel's section, let me please highlight in Slide #13 that today, we are presenting again a solid set of results. We are posting strong organic growth and progress on our additional value-enhancing initiatives. We are taking the first step to be come a European leader in the DAS and small cells sector. We are creating a European platform, executing value-accretive acquisitions that improve our business profile. We have a robust capital structure in place. Enough firepower is still available to continue growing while optimizing funding alternatives. We continue to pursue growth opportunities with discipline and with a selective M&A approach. We are successfully integrating our recent portfolios into Cellnex. And Cellnex is today recognized as the player best positioned to consolidate the European tower landscape.
Now please allow me to hand over to José Manuel Aisa, our CFO and M&A Director, who will go through our 2016 business and financial performance. So please, José Manuel.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tobías. Good afternoon. As a reminder, please note that additional information can be obtained on the Investor Relations sections of our website, where there is a detailed expense [ph] file and should be also the annuals accounts of the compan
componenttext:
Thank you, Tobías. Good afternoon. As a reminder, please note that additional information can be obtained on the Investor Relations sections of our website, where there is a detailed expense [ph] file and should be also the annuals accounts of the company.
So if now we go to slide 15, you can see here the evolution of PoPs and our consolidated tenancy ratio, with increases mainly explained by consistent organic growth and change of perimeter. We have managed to add more than 900 dynamic [ph] PoPs in the period, reaching a tenancy ratio of 1.62, including M&A. 
Additionally, we are pursuing new organic growth opportunities in all business areas with a special mention to framework agreements with mobile operators, entering new markets, decommissioning and build-to-suit projects and other recent agreements with JCDecaux to strengthen our position in the small cells market. 
This balance sheet applies when opportunity arise in Spain and Italy for initial period of 18 months. In venue [ph] with current JCDecaux presence or when a new tender process is launched to manage advertising sites, and is based on a preferred partner approach, relying on JCDecaux's exiting capabilities and adding on top of that our own capabilities to increase the value position.
Moving to slide 16, you can see here the progress of our efficiency plan. As anticipated last year, the main contributor to this program is our site management project, with around 30% of the targeted savings already achieved. We have devoted CapEx of EUR 31 million between cash advance and land acquisition with paybacks of 5 years and average saving around lease, about 20%, with a resulting contract length beyond 15 years. We're also making good progress on our additional initiatives with around 50% of the targeted savings already achieved. Our ultimate objective for the efficiency plan will be for savings to offset higher future costs due to the pricing and increased operating activity so we can show a flat OpEx performance on a like-for-like basis going forward.
On the next slide, you can find a comprehensive explanation of our adjusted EBITDA evolution. You can see how the negative impact of the DTT simulcast in 2015 is more than offset by the switch-on of the new TV channels, together with organic growth contribution and change of perimeter, explaining the strong adjusted EBITDA increase in the year of 23%, in other words, EUR 290 million of adjusted EBITDA.
If we now focus on the adjusted EBITDA margin evolution on the next slide, operating leverage coming from organic growth increases our margin by 1%, broadcasting by an additional 2%. And if we adjust for pass-through costs and revenues, we end up with an adjusted EBITDA margin of 43%.
Slide 19. We will now focus on our capital allocation for the year. We have devoted 90% of our total investment to M&A with 8% allocated to expansion CapEx. We deploy organic growth CapEx with a strict return criteria of low teens unlevered IRR. And as you can see, the majority has been dedicated in 2016 to our efficiency plan.
Slide 20, regarding capital structure. Our debt maturities' profile as of February 2016 presents the first maturity -- or an average maturity of around 7 years, with no material refinancing required before 2022, and protection against potential interest rates hikes due to the fixed cost nature of our debt.
Slide 21. There, we provide an updated snapshot of our capital structure after our last bond issue in January. We have a long-term capital structure in place at attractive terms, with EUR 1.8 billion of liquidity between cash and available credit lines.
Let me now explain on slide 22, our recurring levered free cash flow generation in the period. I would like to start by highlighting that the cash conversion ratio of EBITDA into recurring levered free cash flow in the period has been a strong 87%, with the total figure increasing 30% when compared to the recurrent levered free cash flow of 2015.
Looking now to revenues. The contribution from all the different businesses line increase with our very well-contained cost base, leading to an adjusted EBITDA growth of 23% when compared to last year. Maintenance CapEx is in line with our guidance of 3% of revenues. And our change in working capital is positive due to a one-off revenue collection measures, but expected to be neutral going forward, in line with our guidance. Interest rates reflects our capital structure as of December, with coupons already paid in Q3 and taxes reflecting the implementation of tax management measures. 
All-in-all, we are posting a 15% revenue growth, which implies almost doubling our recurrent levered free cash flow growth when compared to last year.
Moving now to our balance sheet on slide 23. Cellnex leverage for the period has reached 4.6x net debt annualized EBITDA after investing more than EUR 700 million in the year. Our balance sheet reflects the increase in fixed assets due to our recent acquisitions. Recurrent net profit, adjusted for one-off noncash task tax effect last year, increases 38%. And net interest increased mainly due to accrued cost in the year.
On shareholder remuneration, we will pay EUR 22 million in 2017, a 10% increase over the dividend paid in 2016.
Moving to M&A activity in 2015 -- '16, sorry. On slide 24, we explain what we believe is a new paradigm in the tower industry: our ability to create master service agreement with our clients from scratch, making sure these services will not be accounted for debt, as -- if it were accounted following IFRS 16. We offer a wide array of services beyond pure real estate in order to strengthen our long-term relationships with our clients.
Slide 25, you can see here how we think about cash flow generation from recent acquisitions. The cash conversion ratio from EBITDA into recurrent levered free cash flow is above 60%, and the new deals are expected to generate EUR 103 million on a pro forma full year basis, around 26% of the recurrent levered free cash flow generated in 2016. Please note that all these estimations, especially the recurrent levered free cash flow, is after considering financial expenses borne by Cellnex. 
And all this has been achieved with an efficiency -- efficient and flexible capital structure and by applying our strict investment criteria.
Moving to slide 26 in terms of financial outlook for 2017. We believe we can provide a recurrent levered free cash flow at least 10% higher than in 2016, in line with consensus. Looking at the different contribution lines, it is important to highlight that our adjusted EBITDA is expected to reach between EUR 330 million and EUR 340 million. Our CapEx guidance, both maintenance and expansion, remains unchanged. And dividend payable in 2017 will increase 10% compared to 2016. 
There are other things that belong to recurrent levered free cash flow, such as the working capital. That should tend to be neutral; also the interest expense paid. That should follow our coupons; and finally, the tax payment. That should be slightly below -- slightly above our payment in 2016.
Finally, knowing -- I think that is, what's next? We are focusing on several opportunities in Europe, both proprietary and auctions, while maintaining our strict investment discipline. 
The next section addresses several key topics that are very well covered in the slides. This is a new section that we have called "Frequently Asked Questions." But I think that these questions will come across in the -- in your Q&A session. 
So please allow [ph] -- please -- with this, we can start the Q&A session.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Simon Coles from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Simon Coles from Barclays.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Simon Coles from Barclays. I was just wondering if you could give us a few more details about the partnership that you signed with JCDecaux, and maybe some indication on how the economics are going to work on this partnership. Then my second quest
componenttext: This is Simon Coles from Barclays. I was just wondering if you could give us a few more details about the partnership that you signed with JCDecaux, and maybe some indication on how the economics are going to work on this partnership. Then my second question is around the Bouygues deal, I'm just wondering, is this the sort of structure for deals that you'd like to do in the future, in that you stagger the payment and the transfer of title if you're buying towers? Or you say that you can remain flexible with your -- on the balance sheet? And then final question, just a quick one. If you have any guidance for midterm outlook for the Netherlands and the U.K. I know they're very stable businesses and very cash generative. I just wondered if you have any thoughts on that.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, first on the JCDecaux answer. This is Alex Mestre, Chief Commercial Officer. This agreement certainly has been signed recently. It is sort of an agreement that we are both parties trying to have a common approach to the market. We've been tryin
componenttext: Yes. Well, first on the JCDecaux answer. This is Alex Mestre, Chief Commercial Officer. This agreement certainly has been signed recently. It is sort of an agreement that we are both parties trying to have a common approach to the market. We've been trying to deal with the small cells as a initial deployment for this new market. And both together, we believe we can add jointly a set of tools together that can speed up a little bit the deployment of this market. Our budget is not being influenced by this agreement so far. We need to see yet the go-to-market on the 2 countries where we are initially having these commercial agreement in both sides. And we intend to at least continue with the growth on DAS and the small cells. We categorize both product lines into a single one, which is what we call "densification of macro sides into smaller sites." And here, we can attack the market with 2 products: DAS, which is distributed antenna systems; or small cells. We've reached 13% growth during 2016 and we expect that we should be able, of course, to follow the same growth we've been achieving so far. And taking into account, there is on page 31, an assumption on how we understand the market will grow from 2018 onwards up to 2025, where the analysts are projecting a CAGR of roughly 20% per year. So that's the intended approach onto that market, both parties together. There are 3 slides devoted on the appendix -- 4 slides actually, from slide 30 to slide 33, which are focusing all the different topologies of deployment for densification. And there is one as well related to the JCDecaux.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first question Simon, you were asking about the structure of the Bouygues deal, if that is something that we would want to replicate going forward? [indiscernible] José can...
componenttext: Yes. So first question Simon, you were asking about the structure of the Bouygues deal, if that is something that we would want to replicate going forward? [indiscernible] José can...

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that the Bouygues deal represents the -- a good example of what we will like to implement in the next deals. First of all, it's a deal that is coming from an MNO, so directly from the client, this is really important, in which we can develop
componenttext: Yes, I think that the Bouygues deal represents the -- a good example of what we will like to implement in the next deals. First of all, it's a deal that is coming from an MNO, so directly from the client, this is really important, in which we can develop our competitive advantage. And if you ask me, which is the competitive advantage of Cellnex compared to the other players, I would say it's to be able to sit down with a client and to draft from scratch a new MSA. And a new MSA, which is no longer an MLA. We have evolved here in towering in Europe, allow us to step-by-step be in the front door and to develop new concepts to understand the needs of our clients to meet these needs and to create value in the long term for both. No, these are win-win agreements. So yes, this is a new paradigm that meets not only the requirements in terms of technical aspects, but also from accountancy aspects, as this is no longer IFRS 16 lease, but it is a pure service, as pure infrastructure to service as you can find in other sectors.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: There was a last question on opportunities in the Netherlands and the U.K.
componenttext: There was a last question on opportunities in the Netherlands and the U.K.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Oh, the Netherlands and the U.K. are in the first step of our development in every country. Only to remind you that we categorized -- we have 3 categories or 3 steps on our market development. The first one is an interaction on every country where we alwa
componenttext: Oh, the Netherlands and the U.K. are in the first step of our development in every country. Only to remind you that we categorized -- we have 3 categories or 3 steps on our market development. The first one is an interaction on every country where we always identify small opportunities, relatively speaking. We are talking about hundreds of towers always, and allows us to get direct relationship with the customers and to identify further opportunity for growth. The growth gaining in scale is the second step in our market development. And the third one, while we are in the second step, we are always talking about thousand of towers approximately in the transaction. And then at the third stage is where we have a nationwide coverage or nationwide footprint. And when we are able to approach our customers and then to -- should meet decommissioning programs in order to capture and to maximize the efficiency on top of the organic growth. So all-in-all, means that we have identified previously, potential next steps in the Netherlands and in the U.K. As you can imagine, we cannot disclose our potential next steps in every single country, but no doubts about potential opportunities in the Netherlands, in the U.K. Otherwise, we didn't invest on those attractive markets.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Giles Thorne from Dan (sic) [Jefferies].
componenttext: Your next question comes from Giles Thorne from Dan (sic) [Jefferies].

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have 3 questions, please. This is Giles Thorne here from Jefferies. The first one was on Italy, and specifically, Fastweb has spoken about a small cell deployment in that country in the 3.5 gigahertz spectrum range that it had acquired with Tiscali last
componenttext: I have 3 questions, please. This is Giles Thorne here from Jefferies. The first one was on Italy, and specifically, Fastweb has spoken about a small cell deployment in that country in the 3.5 gigahertz spectrum range that it had acquired with Tiscali last year. And now they've spoken about actually using a proprietary cabinet footprint in Italy for the small cell deployment. But it would be interesting to know if there will be any opportunity for Cellnex to support that. Or do you think Fastweb will rely solely on their own infrastructure? And the second question that kind of leads on from that. And the -- and it's also another question about the JCDecaux commercial alliance. Now small cell deployments comes with many challenges and not the least, getting access to the ground level street furniture. We've seen with Fastweb, they'll try and use their own cabinets. So when it comes to the JCDecaux commercial alliance, it seems like you've got a fantastic opportunity to get access to that ground infrastructure. Now it's just Spain, initially, at the moment, but should we expect to see the geographic scope of that commercial alliance expanded? And also, will that commercial alliance sit with the Commscon management team? And so a question there on JCDecaux. And then lastly, on the Bouygues deal, and you've touched on this already, but it does feel like a bellwether for European outsourcing. It's amongst a very few MNO sale and leaseback deals that haven't been driven by leverage pressures at the MNO. It'd be interesting to know how you found working with the Bouygues management team and compare that to other management teams at other MNOs. And also, any sense that there are discussions for expanding that agreement? Are you doing more sale and leasebacks in France?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Alex will answer your first questions from the small cells.
componenttext: Alex will answer your first questions from the small cells.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, in relation to deployment of small cells into the dense urban areas, you are right. There are several, let's call it, "urban real estate" that can be used. We have already today in our existing contract with Barcelona City Hall, we have experience o
componenttext: Okay, in relation to deployment of small cells into the dense urban areas, you are right. There are several, let's call it, "urban real estate" that can be used. We have already today in our existing contract with Barcelona City Hall, we have experience on running out through traffic lights and pole lamps. Also in Milano, we are using light poles to deploy small cells. To have the cabinets is, yes, another possibility, and I think is one of the new areas, as well as using advertising panels. And this is, let's say, how we see our agreement with JCDecaux, which is another potential real estate. Technically, there are certain characteristics that this Euro real estate must have, is that it has to have some height, cannot be just close to the floor. So you need ideally 3 meters, 4 meters height in order to do the small coverage that the small cell is supposed to do. The agreement on -- moving to the second question, I understand if you were wondering whether the agreement we are having today with JCDecaux could be exported to other regions other than the first 2. Absolutely yes. However, since we understood it's first better to test in the areas where Cellnex is already having a very important footprint, we decided to do this first commercial agreement in those 2 countries. And in relation to the third questions, I may start, and Tobias, you may follow. I think the point is...

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

componenttext: Yes, that's right. So it seems to me the Bouygues management has shown a very progressive mentality towards passive infrastructure, more progressive than any other operator who didn't have leverage constraints. So it'd be interesting to know how your experience there differed with the type of conversations you're having with other operators.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: No, thank you. This is a very good example of our strategy. As José Manuel said before, for us, is very, very, very different when we transact with customer rather than other players in the market. I mean, to develop the customer relationship is key for
componenttext: No, thank you. This is a very good example of our strategy. As José Manuel said before, for us, is very, very, very different when we transact with customer rather than other players in the market. I mean, to develop the customer relationship is key for us. If you remember our first transaction with Bouygues in September. And only, let me say only. I'll remark: only after 4 months, we, together with the Bouygues management team and us, we have been able to reach an agreement on a thousand of assets and a very high quality of assets. So very sensitive transaction for both parties. And this is the reason why I fully agree with you. Management of Bouygues, I think, it's very positive, is very open to consider maybe even a full outsourcing on the existing infrastructures. Well -- and not only on the existing infrastructure, sorry, because we had reached a very important build-to-suit program of 1,200 new infrastructure.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had a few questions as well. Firstly in terms of your decommissioning schedules, sort of 2,000 sites. You're saying 25% is in progress. What does that actually mean? Does that mean we could expect that to happen in 2017 and it's sort of already included
componenttext: I had a few questions as well. Firstly in terms of your decommissioning schedules, sort of 2,000 sites. You're saying 25% is in progress. What does that actually mean? Does that mean we could expect that to happen in 2017 and it's sort of already included in your guidance? And then on the same topic, so the remaining 75%, is that for the same operator as -- or operators as the first 75% -- or 25%? And then I guess a little but more generally, you got quite a few growth opportunities going on. You're looking at new markets, you're doing small cells and DAS and you're consolidating your existing markets. If you sort of, I guess, firstly prioritize, what is it you're working the most with? And then I guess maybe that's the same order, but which of these options are you -- or opportunities are you the most excited about and think will contribute the most if we look a couple of years out? I think that's it.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, in relation to your first question on decommissioning, yes, certainly now, we are on at least 25% of achievement. I think that the first relevant element here is that we are proving that decommissioning is something that is feasible totally, no? Beca
componenttext: Yes, in relation to your first question on decommissioning, yes, certainly now, we are on at least 25% of achievement. I think that the first relevant element here is that we are proving that decommissioning is something that is feasible totally, no? Because this has been repeatedly a question that you've been mentioning as well. But this is not -- well, it is possible and we are actually doing. The reality is, and this is also true, that it has taken a little bit more time on the preparation for the plans of decommissioning which is quite detailed analysis of pairs of towers, the operator's towers, our tower, define which is the survivor tower, how to move the fiber if the fiber is there. So it is a very detailed technical analysis that has to be performed before moving ahead with the decision of decommissioning a tower. I think the second part of this question was whether if the remaining 75%, we intend to shift with only one operator or several?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, the idea is, as we can -- we said earlier, we are currently in 5 countries, but we are in different stage of market development. So we want to develop in every single country, our strategy in order to gain in scale for growth and then to be able for
componenttext: Well, the idea is, as we can -- we said earlier, we are currently in 5 countries, but we are in different stage of market development. So we want to develop in every single country, our strategy in order to gain in scale for growth and then to be able for consolidation. This is our first priority. Second one, focus remain our target. I mean, we are looking for opportunities in Europe. Sometimes, the opportunities will come because -- as a public tender, as a competitive process. But the company, it's working always very proactively, approaching customers in identifying opportunities. And then, let me say, to create or to define new opportunities in our bilateral discussions. Obviously, I cannot disclose in which and where we are working, but well, we have a very attractive pipeline of opportunities in Europe. And we will disclose them in -- when we execute or when we can disclose.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions from me on the PoP growth, organic PoP growth. You achieved 4.5% in 2016, which is better than your guidance. Do you expect to achieve this growth rate again this year? And then again on the PoP growth, the 3%, 4% over 2016, 2019, I assum
componenttext: Just 2 questions from me on the PoP growth, organic PoP growth. You achieved 4.5% in 2016, which is better than your guidance. Do you expect to achieve this growth rate again this year? And then again on the PoP growth, the 3%, 4% over 2016, 2019, I assume this is an average overall, all countries, but do you expect to see a lot of differences in terms of growth per country?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Charles, on the guidance for PoP provided for the medium term, basically, what -- we want to be consistent with the guidance we provided at the beginning of the year. It is true that we have been ahead of our guidance in terms of organic growth for this y
componenttext: Charles, on the guidance for PoP provided for the medium term, basically, what -- we want to be consistent with the guidance we provided at the beginning of the year. It is true that we have been ahead of our guidance in terms of organic growth for this year. Mostly you go to Q3, there was quite a high activity. In any case, even the landing [ph] profile of how we attract new PoPs every quarter, I think it's important for us to provide exactly the same view for the medium term. So that is why we are keeping this 3%, 4% guidance in the medium term. With any more information we get from our customers, we might be adjusting that. But this is the result of our information we have today and that I will feel comfortable with. In terms of organic growth being generated by different countries, exactly the same as you have seen in 2016. The profile will be consistent. Countries are providing similar levels of organic growth, so, obviously with slight differences. For example, in Netherlands, you know that, that tenancy rate is already quite high. But on the previous markets, we are expecting a stabilizing, as seen in 2016.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ottavio Adorisio from Societe Generale.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ottavio Adorisio from Societe Generale.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have 3 question, if I may. The first one is on JCDecaux. I have to be honest, I was bit surprised in that one because, basically in 2014, Vodafone did sign similar agreements with them. It's a worldwide agreement. It's a 15-year contract and it's almost
componenttext: I have 3 question, if I may. The first one is on JCDecaux. I have to be honest, I was bit surprised in that one because, basically in 2014, Vodafone did sign similar agreements with them. It's a worldwide agreement. It's a 15-year contract and it's almost the same sort of content of the agreements you signed yourself. So I would like to, if possible, for you to give some color, how it's going to work between the 3 of you. Is Vodafone going to have access to the same sites that you're going to use? And you're going to have an overlapping of different sites, and so on and so forth? The second one is on Italy. I've seen that you're recording actually good growth on the PoPs. Now it's no secret anymore that WIND and Hutchison are basically merging. WIND is basically honoring the contract. And therefore, it's very likely that the Hutchinson tender will be moving at some stage. So I was wondering, if have you seen any movements on that side. I've seen that the growth in Italy is relatively robust, especially when compared to Spain. And I was wondering who are the PoPs that actually are moving towards your towers? The third, it's a followup from a previous answer to JCDecaux again. I was talking about the fact that the budget for the JCDecaux has not been formulated or places have not been finalized. So I was wondering is that -- means that the free cash flow guidance you provide today, it's gross of any investments you have to make on that particular agreement? Or it's basically already been accounted on your free cash flow guidance?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. In relation to your first question, honestly, we do not know the details on all the potential agreements that our partner may be having. The truth is that, at any moment, we've been having any kind of restriction on rolling out the go-to-market of t
componenttext: Okay. In relation to your first question, honestly, we do not know the details on all the potential agreements that our partner may be having. The truth is that, at any moment, we've been having any kind of restriction on rolling out the go-to-market of the agreement, which is only commercial, going to your last point, but it is on the commercial agreement on those 2 markets. So, so far we do not foresee any restriction with any MNO on deploying this agreement in Spain and Italy. The second question was, actually in Italy -- the growth in Italy, no? So growth in Italy has several factors. I think we've been also press [ph] releasing some agreement we've been having with one, let's say, broadband operator in Italy. This is one of the elements. Also one of our several decommissioning projects is in Italy, which in turn, brings also additional point of presence. And that's basically the main elements about, let's say, the regular growth that has been guided into this presentation that we are having in Italy.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And regarding the third question, Ottavio, we have presented to you what we think is our proven approach to 2017. And I think everything is embedded there, okay? If during the year, our view has to be updated, we will share with you as we have done, but s
componenttext: And regarding the third question, Ottavio, we have presented to you what we think is our proven approach to 2017. And I think everything is embedded there, okay? If during the year, our view has to be updated, we will share with you as we have done, but so far, this is our best estimation.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

For the 2 countries where you're going to cooperate with them, would you have access to all their sites or there has been some restrictions?

componenttext: Full access to any sites that we generally may have. So in that sense, there is no restriction.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Fernando Cordero from Banco Santander.
componenttext: The next question comes from Fernando Cordero from Banco Santander.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The first one is just a follow-up on the 2017 guidance and also understanding what is your, how can I say, way of presenting the guidance, I just would like to check if the building blocks exercise for this guidance is as we're going to, how can I say, fo
componenttext: The first one is just a follow-up on the 2017 guidance and also understanding what is your, how can I say, way of presenting the guidance, I just would like to check if the building blocks exercise for this guidance is as we're going to, how can I say, foreseeing the [indiscernible] after the  EUR 275 million organic or -- sorry, EUR 279 million and EBITDA for 2016 plus the EUR 38 million, EUR 39 million EBITDA coming from a change of perimeter during the year 2016. It implies that the guidance is assuming that the organic growth is going to be between 3% and 4% at the retail growth and in this organic growth [indiscernible] just would like to, how can I say, check the math and at which extent this organic growth is quite conservative? My second question is regarding the growth expansion of CapEx, the organic expansion of CapEx, and particularly on the effort that you have made during 2016 on efficiencies and particularly on ground leases. In that sense, I just would like to know first, at which extent have you been buying land, not just renegotiating the ground leases contract? And to what extent should we expect the same activity or the same CapEx for the next couple of years? And finally, on the dividend, although you just were clear that Cellnex is not focusing yet on dividend, I would like just to, how can I say, to know if you are changing your dividend policy as you are guiding for 10% growth in dividend for 2017? Or if it's just, how can I say,  derived from the fact that your recurrent levered free cash flow just got below 10%, so 20% of this free cash flow volume [ph] is just growing 10%. Or in other words, what could -- what should be the dividend policy going forward? 10% growth per year or 20% of the peak cash flow?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The first question is, it's about your estimates on our guidance we gave to you. Listen, there is -- regarding the Bouygues deal, we do think that in 2017, the impact of Bouygues deal on the EBITDA should be rather limited, okay. So when doing your estima
componenttext: The first question is, it's about your estimates on our guidance we gave to you. Listen, there is -- regarding the Bouygues deal, we do think that in 2017, the impact of Bouygues deal on the EBITDA should be rather limited, okay. So when doing your estimation, please factor into the equation this that being conservative or not will depend also on a change of perimeter of the impact of this leading to the -- into the equation, okay? So regarding your second question, which is about the expansion of CapEx. You are right. We have, I think we have been quite happy with this program. Most of the program, cash from renegotiation and cash advances done ground-lease acquisitions, okay. So this is something that is important to say. And very specially, when you say what's going on in those years, you can see that this EUR 57 million represents 7.5% of the total revenues, which is within our guidance between 5% and 10% of revenues diverted to expansion CapEx. I do think we will follow this guidance. So step-by-step, I think that we will be able to increase further the ground lease renegotiation program, which is very interesting. And finally, regarding your dividend statement, we -- let me say to you that this dividend -- this dividend suggestion, this dividend payment in 2017, '18, '19, it's a crystallization of our dividend policy. If you know that the 20% recurrent levered free cash flow had to be commensurate with also the growth of the company, the net income of the company. So we do think that this is a crystallization for 3 years that in quantity of money that makes sense with all the patterns that we commensurate this 20% recurrent levered [ph] free cash flow. So our dividend policy was a little bit maybe more developed than what you say. I think that's all, Fernando. Thank you very much.

componenttext: Just, if I may, a followup question on the ground leases and given your current experience, what you are finding the most interesting, how can I say, financial profile of the ground lease renegotiation? Renegotiating? Buying the land?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sorry, just to clarify, Fernando, we have seen that cash advances is a very powerful tool. I would say that this is representing the -- maybe the savings we are seeing today are mostly coming from this. Buying land is something we are starting to do, but
componenttext: Sorry, just to clarify, Fernando, we have seen that cash advances is a very powerful tool. I would say that this is representing the -- maybe the savings we are seeing today are mostly coming from this. Buying land is something we are starting to do, but going forward, that could be also a very powerful weapon to take into consideration.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Parin Shah from Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question comes from Parin Shah from Bank of America.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's Parin Shah from Bank of America. I've got 3 questions. The first one is, so in the U.K., I guess, there's enough available that are of significant scale, but it would also mean dialing back the progress you've been making in reducing the broadcast ex
componenttext: It's Parin Shah from Bank of America. I've got 3 questions. The first one is, so in the U.K., I guess, there's enough available that are of significant scale, but it would also mean dialing back the progress you've been making in reducing the broadcast exposure in your portfolio. So would you tolerate, I guess, bidding for this asset and would cement create scale on a Big 5 European market or it is something you wouldn't really consider because of the progress you made on broadcast in reducing that exposure? Question two, so the Bouygues tower deal, I think that's a bit appreciated. It's quite an interesting deal. I was just wondering whether you could confirm the sale process was conducted on an exclusive basis with Cellnex being the only bidder. And I was wondering whether you are confident that you can carry on doing this in future negotiations, essentially wondering why wouldn't an operator not choose to conduct discussions with multiple parties, including American Tower. And just on that, did that provide support for you pulling out of an FPS deal where otherwise you'd be bidding at quite an elevated multiple. And question 3, on your growth guidance. I guess there could be a material step change in growth in some of your geographies, particularly in Italy, if -- and depending on when the 4th operator chooses to build. Would you consider such growth to be incremental to your 3% to 4% guidance? And those are the questions.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, many questions. I don't -- let's see if I'm able to answer all of them. Otherwise, you help me to remind because there has been quite a set of questions. Well, your first question was talking about Activa, [ph]no? And Activa [ph] since [ph] any othe
componenttext: Well, many questions. I don't -- let's see if I'm able to answer all of them. Otherwise, you help me to remind because there has been quite a set of questions. Well, your first question was talking about Activa, [ph]no? And Activa [ph] since [ph] any other investment in the last case for Cellnex has to comply our strict M&A criteria. And this is very important. I mean, if not, I'm very sorry, we'll not be Activa or nothing else. Just to remind very quickly, our M&A criteria is low, double-digit in terms of equity IRR. Second, improvement of our cash flow visibility of business risk profile. And finally, the accretive impact on our recurrent free cash flow per share from year 2 onwards. So it's quite strict and this criteria and just to answer another question you were saying, regarding FPS, was your fourth question, I think. You said to ask that obviously, this opportunity did not meet our criteria. So I'm very sorry. All that will come could [ph] not [ph] happen [ph] our criteria. So when talking about American Tower, which is your third question, I think, American Tower has always been there. It's not the first time it has been in Europe. Back in 2011, it was competing with us with all those towers in -- with our first towers in Spain. So it has always been there. And our competitor advantage is not only debt from payment, it's as we said before in another question, another answer, is to be able to sit down with a client to build up a new MSA contract to understand their needs. That's really important. And your second question was about Bouygues -- Bouygues? The process was a competitive process. Of course, it was a competitive process. Maybe it was not in the press everyday, but it was competitive. And if we were able to win, it's because we were able to do a unique offer. And unique offer from many angles, not only the upfront payment, but also our capacity to understand their needs today and tomorrow. And in order to do so, you need credentials. You need industrial angle, you need partnership in the long term and this make us unique in comparison with others. And finally, you are talking about, I think it was growth and MNO. Unfortunately, [indiscernible] vocal. Should have an impact in 2018, not before. We have been consistent with this message. So -- and what the guidance represented to you is consistent.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, that was very clear. I guess, I've just got one more question. Just in terms of your EBITDA guidance for next year, would you say that's quite conservative? Does it take maybe a more pessimistic view of your business? Or I mean, it did -- to me it l
componenttext: Okay, that was very clear. I guess, I've just got one more question. Just in terms of your EBITDA guidance for next year, would you say that's quite conservative? Does it take maybe a more pessimistic view of your business? Or I mean, it did -- to me it looks a little low, especially considering where consensus is sitting.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: It is the same answer as before. I cannot change the answer. It depends -- first of all, we are a proven company, and we have a big staff, record of commitment and deliveries. Second, I will say to you that we can, it's clearly stated in update, should cr
componenttext: It is the same answer as before. I cannot change the answer. It depends -- first of all, we are a proven company, and we have a big staff, record of commitment and deliveries. Second, I will say to you that we can, it's clearly stated in update, should crystallize very limited -- in a very limited way into '17. So please, if we -- if this change, we will somehow share with you new views, but in the meantime, this is our best...

componenttextpreview: Estimation and we will see in the next coming quarters. So we have to be prudent, if I may.
componenttext: Estimation and we will see in the next coming quarters. So we have to be prudent, if I may.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

componenttext: Your next question comes from Luigi Minerva from HSBC.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sorry. I was on mute. The first one is on the Bouygues deal. And I was wondering if you can -- if you are able to may be to share some color of -- about the deal maybe from the mobile network operator's perspective, and particularly with regards to the tr
componenttext: Sorry. I was on mute. The first one is on the Bouygues deal. And I was wondering if you can -- if you are able to may be to share some color of -- about the deal maybe from the mobile network operator's perspective, and particularly with regards to the treatment in the IFRS '16 empowerment. So the service agreement that you have. Will Bouygues have to basically report it as part of a long-term lease in their net debt definition? Or does it stay out of the net debt with IFRS '16 new rules? The second question is on the cross-border synergies. I mean, traditionally other tower companies have always stated there are no synergies. I see you have a slide in your presentation making the case for it. If you can probably a bit elaborate on your views on that, I think you are in better position than others in Europe to comment on that? And thirdly, just to go back on the dividend guidance and the dividend outlook. So if I understand well, your numbers, effectively, we are talking about EUR 0.091 of DPS in 2016, which can become EUR 0.10 in 2017. Now consensus on Bloomberg for '17 is about EUR 0.21. So are we getting this right that you are well below consensus on your new dividend outlook?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, many questions, Luigi. Let's see. First was about IFRS '16. We -- I don't know how the different our, what do you say, guidance contributes to our country's perspective. What I can tell you is that we are working on MSAs, not longer in MLAs, which m
componenttext: Well, many questions, Luigi. Let's see. First was about IFRS '16. We -- I don't know how the different our, what do you say, guidance contributes to our country's perspective. What I can tell you is that we are working on MSAs, not longer in MLAs, which means that IFRS '16 defines very well what is a lease and what is not a lease. And therefore, if anyone understands the criteria and takes our contract, we'll categorize this contract as an MSA and therefore [indiscernible] under IFRS '15. But this is the treatment -- the accountancy treatment depends on the different parties. Regarding the cross-border synergies on page 34, the only intention of Page 34 is to tell you that when talking about cross borders, you have to look at the countries, yes, so the clients. At the end of the day, if our great advantage is to sit down and to develop a new contract with our client and therefore, if you have already a common way of communication with this client, this can be somehow repetitive knowledge [indiscernible], no? That's very important. So towering is our clients, not about towers only, okay? You were talking also about.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: What? On the dividend.
componenttext: What? On the dividend.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The dividend, yes, and this is also that Fernando raised the point and obviously, the market consensus would say, dividends were following the 20% recurrent levered free cash flow. And now we're saying to you that we crystallize this 20% recurrent levered
componenttext: The dividend, yes, and this is also that Fernando raised the point and obviously, the market consensus would say, dividends were following the 20% recurrent levered free cash flow. And now we're saying to you that we crystallize this 20% recurrent levered free cash flow commensurate with net income M&A growth. We crystallize for 3 years 10% growth in relation to 2016 payment. And therefore, this is a new guidance and cannot match the consensual that you have in front of you. We do think it makes sense for this new 3 years to do what we'll have to, which is to create value for our shareholders.

componenttext: Maybe just to add on top of that is that there is a broad consensus at EU level that sub 700 megahertz is going to be mainly devoted to broadcasting. componenttext: I'll try to be quick. Just probably starting to [indiscernible] a bit. Just 2 quick one on the small cells economics. And second, just you have a slide talking about close to, I think, EUR 1.8 billion of available financing that you have now. Quite a lot of that will be amount for the retail deal. I mean, do you generally have that much headroom in terms of tackling all the new opportunities that you're talking about? componenttext: In relation to the small cells, we devoted 4 slides trying to give some color on the business model. Page 30, there are 2 of the basic business models. I think with all that information, you will be able to figure out a little bit the main terms and parameters of how this could work. headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Finally, regarding the credit lines available. Listen, we do have, I mean, I think this is very good news to have first of all, long-term maturity scheme in front of us. In the next 5 years, we will have headrooms of how to use this credit lines. And this
componenttext: Finally, regarding the credit lines available. Listen, we do have, I mean, I think this is very good news to have first of all, long-term maturity scheme in front of us. In the next 5 years, we will have headrooms of how to use this credit lines. And this is a lot of money, EUR 1.8 billion. Obviously, we'll fund many projects or should fund many projects, one of them being Bouygues, but also be aware that Bouygues deal is not going to be paid tomorrow. As we have been saying this is a process. And using this process, we will also generate more cash. So I wouldn't say EUR 1.8 billion less EUR 800 million, they'll have EUR 1 billion, no, I will say that the beauty of this project is that somehow we have time to invest. And I don't think that right now if you look at how much money Cellnex has invested in the last years, we have invested roughly speaking around EUR 1.5 billion. We have EUR 1.8 billion to invest more. So I think it makes sense. That's a lot of money. And as you know, Nicolas, you can't use this money just to acquire 100% of the enterprise value or maybe 51% of our target, which is levered. So this is a multiplier. So it depends how you fund the deal in terms of partners, partners yes, partners no; finance, yes or no. So maybe it's more sophisticated than say, okay this is the headroom. That's all. Game over. There are many things here that will be commensurate with the answer.

componenttext: Well, Nicolas, we've always been clear in this regard from the very beginning in the APR also [indiscernible] you got 4x on average in the long-term makes sense, and this is the point, which means, some years we'll be above 4 and other years below 4. At an average, we have to have a healthy, as you say [indiscernible] 4x, in my view 4x EBITDA makes sense in a company that has a backlog that is impressive. I mean, our backlog and you can check this in the presentation also and in our accounts EUR 12 billion. This is the backlog we have right now. So net debt EBITDA is a good estimation, but I wouldn't use as the only estimate or 2 to see if the company is highly leveraged, below leverage or whatever. I think is one criteria, but there are several angles in it.

componenttext: So just 2 very quick questions from my side. The first one still relating to the fourth quarter results. But given the multiple they paid for FPS towers, do you feel that they are more aggressive now?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017

componenttext: On the quarters, on quarterly OpEx, I will remind that we do see some fluctuation in terms of -- maybe some quarters you can see some utilities' adjustments. General services, for example, that depends on one-off costs we contract on a year-end quarter. So it's quite difficult for us to give you quite a monolithic figure to try to -- from which to extrapolate going forward. That is why we are comfortable providing you with 2017 guidance, because all in all, OpEx should be performing quite flat with, as you very well mentioned, that you will see some increases coming from increased operations, but also you will see the effect of the [indiscernible]. So all-in-all, you should be expecting OpEx performance on an annual basis similar to 2016. And your second question was about American Tower. I can see the indiscernible]. Listen, I don't know, if they are more aggressive or less than before. We have an M&A criteria. We follow these rules and for us they create a value creation for ourself is key. And we are not going to change this game if American Tower is there or not -- not at all. And...

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: So I know that works maybe -- sorry to interrupt you, Generale, [ph] only to reinforce the message that our project remains important [ph] than the IPO because for us -- I think it -- let me say is a very good news to get American Tower, Europe, but this
componenttext: So I know that works maybe -- sorry to interrupt you, Generale, [ph] only to reinforce the message that our project remains important [ph] than the IPO because for us -- I think it -- let me say is a very good news to get American Tower, Europe, but this is the proof that Europe is attractive for the American Tower company. It's a worldwide leader. There is no doubt about that. So this is a proof that we are in the right market, in the right place, and if you look the U.S. market and benchmark with Europe, you would be agreed, maybe, that we could get 2, 3 big telecom infrastructure companies like in the U.S. markets. So all in all, I think it's the natural development of the European infrastructure telecom market.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, [indiscernible] of Investor Relations. I had like to thank you for joining us today for our Q1 2017 results conference call. I'm joined today by José Manuel Aisa, CFO and Director, who will lead today's p
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, [indiscernible] of Investor Relations. I had like to thank you for joining us today for our Q1 2017 results conference call. 
I'm joined today by José Manuel Aisa, CFO and Director, who will lead today's presentation. We have, as of today, posted our presentation, which we will refer to throughout our prepared remarks, and then we'll open the line for our Q&A session. So please proceed, José.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones of the period on Slide 4. We have again posted a solid set of results based on the following pillars: We continued to generate a strong organi
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones of the period on Slide 4. We have again posted a solid set of results based on the following pillars: We continued to generate a strong organic growth, in line with our guidance; we are improving the visibility on our future organic growth by reaching 2 strategic agreements. First of all, we have signed our frame goal agreement with the fourth mobile operator in Italy, allowing them for fully flexibility on their future network deployment. And second, we have reached a new agreement for the commission of further 400 sites. 
We are reaffirming our 2017 guidance, and I would like to highlight our very high conversion ratio even without great status. That is the highest in the sector. 
We continue to successful -- to successfully tap the credit markets by issuing long terms instruments and very attractive terms. And last but not least, we continue to lead a unique value proposition in the European tower sector based on tailored MSAs, neutrality, long-term approach and a strong relationship with our customers.
On Slide 5, you can see the strong performance of our key value metrics, with adjusted EBITDA growing annually at around 30% and recurring lever free cash flow per share growing at around 10% over the last 2 years.
Moving to Slide 6. Total PoPs have increased by 20%, and our consolidated cash [indiscernible] ratio by 6%. This includes both the contribution of organic growth and the change of perimeter in the period. If we look at organic growth only, new PoPs have increased by 5%, so we are in line with our medium-term organic growth guidance, showing the strength of our current operations. Additionally, DAS nodes have increased 6% in the quarter, and we are working hard to make this new activity a significant contributor to Cellnex revenues going forward.
In terms of organic growth drivers, you can see on Slide 7 our view for our new organic PoPs as well as the progress of our decommissioning and build-to-suit program. New PoPs for multi-tenancy are expected to be generated at a rate in line with our guidance. And these quarterly results confirm this trend.
Our decommissioning program now shows a 45% progress. Thanks to the recent agreement reached to dismantle 400 additional sites. Thus, providing us with even more visibility on our future organic growth.
Progress on our B2C program includes our recent agreement with Bouygues Telecom in France, and we are really taking the first steps in close coordination with our customer.
Before moving to Slide 9 and as a reminder, please note that additional financial information can be obtained from the Investor Relations section of our website where a detailed Excel file is available.
You can see on this slide the evolution of PoPs and our consolidated tenancy ratio, which increases mainly explained by consistent organic growth and change of [ pay meta ]. As you can see, we have managed to add 1,000 organic PoPs [ year ] on a year-by-year basis, with 289 being generated this quarter only. Reaching a tenancy ratio of 1.63, a change of perimeter included.
Also, we are pushing new organic growth opportunities in all businesses. With a special mention to the framework agreement we have recently signed with the fourth mobile operator in Italy, which will provide them with full flexibility for their network employment in the country.
We are so proud to announce a new project for decommissioning of 400 third-party towers. We continue to foresee commercial opportunities in the DAS small cell [indiscernible] and sign a new contract with these systems for the provision of plant support for Inmarsat on board communications solution. 
Last but not least, I would like to remind you that Cellnex expects no impact from the second digital dividend. That DTT spectrum is secured and list until 2030, and that we also expect to benefit from new mobile communication services deployed as a result of more spectrum available to operators.
On the next slide, you can find a comprehensive explanation of our adjusted EBITDA evolution.
You can see how the positive impact of the sweet charm of the new TV channel last year is reinforced by organic growth contribution and change of perimeter, explaining the strong adjusted EBITDA increase in the period of 33%.
Moving to our capital structure, on Slide 11, you can see our debt maturities profile as of April with an average maturity of around 6.5 years. No material for financial required prior to 2022 and a strong protection against potential interest rate increase as a result of the fixed cost nature of our debt.
All in all, we have a long-term capital structure in place at attractive terms with 2 billion of liquidity between cash and available credit lines, providing us with full flexibility to optimize available funding alternatives.
Let me please now explain on Slide 12 our recent lever free cash flow generation in the period.
I would like to start by highlighting that the cash conversion ratio of EBITDA into recurring lever free cash flow in the period has been a strong 84%. 
Looking out to revenues. The contribution from Telecom Infrastructure Services and broadcasting increased. We have very well contained cost base, leading to an adjusted EBITDA growth of 33% when compared to last year.
Maintenance CapEx, this is slightly below our guidance due to the facing. Our change in working capital is turning to neutral. Interest paid reflect our capital structure as of March and its associated coupons. Why will stacks are view later in the year. All in all, we are sowing today a 15% revenue growth, which implies more than doubling our adjusted EBITDA growth when compared to last year.
Moving now to our balance sheet on Slide 23. Cellnex leverage for the period has reached 4.3x net debt annualized EBITDA after investing more than EUR 700 million in the previous months. Compared to December 2016, our balance sheet mostly reflects the increase in debt instruments and its associated cash inflow in the period.
Moving to Slide 14 and as a summary, let me please highlight that. Today, we are presenting again a solid set of results. We are posting a strong and consistent organic growth coupled with our progress on our additional value-creation initiatives such as the framework agreement with the fourth mobile operator in Italy and a new decommissioning project. And finally, we are reiterating our guidance for the full year 2017.
The next section address several key topics that I believe are self explanatory, but I am more than happy to answer any questions you may have. So let's please start the Q&A session.

So you're saying [indiscernible] quite bigger small sales in the U.S. of course, that's quite a few fiber assets in the last year or so. [indiscernible]

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: So regarding the financial flexibility, as you can see, that we do have right now EUR 2 billion in cash and available credit lines. These clear lines are long term, so between 3 and 5 years. And also you know that we have tapped the debt market, the bond
componenttext: So regarding the financial flexibility, as you can see, that we do have right now EUR 2 billion in cash and available credit lines. These clear lines are long term, so between 3 and 5 years. And also you know that we have tapped the debt market, the bond market issuance of 10 years. And on top of that, 2 private placements and I think that also 10 and 9 years. So the thing is that the market, the debt market is giving us without the door open. Our backlog is huge. We're talking about more than EUR 12 billion of backlog. This is recognized by both investors, and I think that the reason why caused the flexibility to fund acquisitions with debt. Also bear in mind something when you have EUR 2 billion of available debt, it's because the perception of the debt community [indiscernible] and bankholders is positive, otherwise, we wouldn't have this money. And so this is not only my perception of flexibility. It's also the perception of the market regarding the next. Also as we were seeing in the last -- in the full year results, Cellnex delevered very quickly, and we estimate that at least 0.6x in terms of net debt to EBITDA should decrease Cellnex in 1 year. So this will give us headroom to grow, headroom to fund [indiscernible]. You have -- You're second question was cons com. And as you know, cons com, we -- it's a great opportunity for us. It's opening -- we are opening up the not only internal market in which cons com was already, but also the Spanish market. We have been building up alliance, as you were suggesting before. And you have here results, I mean, with a strong growth that we open the future and can go on. We are very active in our core markets, very active with CommsCom and the results this step-by-step recognized by clients not only because of the economics or the transaction that we think makes sense for both sides, but also for the very good quality that we're delivering to clients. It's not only it's also question of credibility. It's also a question of credibility of credentials. And I think CommsCom is filling up this credentials, and this is being recognized. And I think [indiscernible], you can explain better than we do second question.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. On your last question. I get that as you know we are developing our strategy in Europe for small cells in the years. [indiscernible] We are far from acquisitions like the ones that is executing in the states. So I guess that initial term, our approa
componenttext: Sure. On your last question. I get that as you know we are developing our strategy in Europe for small cells in the years. [indiscernible] We are far from acquisitions like the ones that is executing in the states. So I guess that initial term, our approach will to make use of existing further assets, so may be by reaching agreements with third parties rather than the executing direct investments. But again, this is something that we are at the earliest stages and that we might consider in the future.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. The first is a pull off from the one you just answer. On top of the time frame, if you can just elaborate a bit of economics of decommission and contract. Basically, the cost of the commissions, I believe, is on your side rather tha
componenttext: A couple of questions. The first is a pull off from the one you just answer. On top of the time frame, if you can just elaborate a bit of economics of decommission and contract. Basically, the cost of the commissions, I believe, is on your side rather than the client side. And if that's the case, what's the breakeven on this contract given the contracts? I don't know if you already signed the full contract or you're just the framework agreement. Just understand when you're going to break even and the sort of return investments you have on this contract you signed in. The second one is on the [indiscernible] side. You signed the contract for in February for delivery -- over delivery -- for basically 1,800 towers that will be only gradually given to you. So just want to -- you said at that time, I remember you mentioned around 2 years. So given now that you've got a bit months, if you have a bit more kind of clarity on when these towers will come, will about will be this year, will be next year? And if the payments are done, [indiscernible] towers comes in or are pain advance. And the third is on tax. You basically mentioned in the presentations and in doing the call about the high conversion rates and then you compare yourself to a number of towers -- tower close in Europe. Most of them are in Italy. Now given your significant exposure to the market and given the fact that the table you show in your presentations so the tenant TowerCo's pay in excess of 10% of the EBITDA while yours at the group level is around only 2%. So my question is how long your 2% is specifically going to stay at this level? And what sort of framework you believe that now that you expand into new markets with that 2% remain as such. Would you basically believe that the tax rate could increase or decrease from here?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you for the question. This is the very last one, and I will the other ones. So the tax, and I remember, Octavio, this question from you at the moment of the IPO. And we have been working on stand as you can see being very consistent with this trend.
componenttext: Thank you for the question. This is the very last one, and I will the other ones. So the tax, and I remember, Octavio, this question from you at the moment of the IPO. And we have been working on stand as you can see being very consistent with this trend. So we are working on that. We have several things, several measures that have been implemented which are very basic one. I don't think this is elaborating these change things. [indiscernible] what's like the amortization depreciation policy. So assessing detail every single CapEx we invest how can we depreciate it according to the law and to make sense. Second, our structure you know that we place our debt in the most, I will say to you, in the most advantaged place so that we make sense when doing old investments would carry out. Third, we'll have also comment that we have a pat and box mechanism. Cellnex is a company that generates no help and is know how we set of contracts, which are fully compliant with the Europenan directories and allow us to show how to take advantage of the regulation in European countries for companies that foster research and development. Also you know that in some specific countries, we are taking into account the national interest reduction and also it's helping us. So it's not only 1 measure. It's several things that, put it together, allow us to take advantage, allow us to comply with the law and to pay what we have to pay. Nothing there, nothing more, nothing less. How long, what -- how long is the same for everything? How long interest rates are going to be like that? How long the organic growth is going to be there? How long our base case scenario is that this policies, this different measure were implemented are long-term issues. I think that this is not something that we take very seriously and always compliance. So and therefore, when you are compliance, you don't have to be worried about how long. There is another angle you were seeing in your second question was about [indiscernible]. You are right then. We communicate to the market I believe this was going to be executed throughout the next quarters. It's not going to be executed in 1 day. And why? Because this is the acquisition of assets. It's not the acquisition of shares. If we were talking about acquisition of shares, we would have [indiscernible] the money and may be we would be having the EBITDA coming into the company but also maybe we were begging more taxes, no? And but to the previous question, the previous answer. So eventually, what we have done is an asset deal. This takes time because we have -- we need a waiver of the landlord. We need to call [indiscernible] with a client. It is my feeling that we will obtain the results that we gave you at the full year 2016 presentation when we gave you the outlook, so limited impact in 2017. We will communicate you quarter by quarter how much we pay and how many towers we receive. Finally, regarding the economics. Again, the same economics we talk in the IPO. So at the moment, we were saying that roughly speaking in general. And when we signed that contract like this contract has been signed is we invest, let's say EUR 24,000, EUR 25,000, EUR 30,000 per the commission side and then we have a payback that is fully compliant with our golden rules for unlevered projects that you know perfectly how these -- the rules are. So we feel comfortable the breakeven, and I think that it takes in terms of payback, I cannot be very explicit but this playback is a good payback, yes.
