headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, Cellnex Head of Investor Relations. I would like to thank you for joining us today for our Q1 2017 results conference call. I'm joined today by José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, who will lead today'
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, Cellnex Head of Investor Relations. I would like to thank you for joining us today for our Q1 2017 results conference call. 
I'm joined today by José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, who will lead today's presentation. We have, as of today, posted our presentation which we will refer to throughout our prepared remarks. And then we'll open the line for a Q&A session. 
So please, José Manuel.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones of the period on Slide 4. We have again posted a solid set of results based on the following pillars. We'll continue to generate a strong or
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones of the period on Slide 4. 
We have again posted a solid set of results based on the following pillars. We'll continue to generate a strong organic growth in line with our guidance. We are improving the visibility on our future organic growth by reaching 2 strategic agreements. First of all, we have signed a framework agreement with the fourth mobile operator in Italy, allowing them for fully flexibility on their future network deployment. And second, we have reached a new agreement for the commission of further 400 sites. 
We are reaffirming our 2017 guidance, and I would like to highlight our very high conversion ratio even without great status that is the highest in the sector. We continue to successful -- to successfully tap the credit markets by issuing long-terms instruments at very attractive terms. And last but not least, we continue to lead a unique value proposition in the European tower sector based on tailored MSAs, neutrality, long-term approach and a strong relationship with our customers.
On Slide 5, you can see the strong performance of our key value metrics, with adjusted EBITDA growing annually at around 30% and recurring levered free cash flow per share growing at around 10% over the last 2 years.
Moving to Slide 6. Total PoPs have increased by 20%, and our consolidated customer ratio by 6%. This includes both the contribution of organic growth and the change of perimeter in the period. If we look at organic growth only, new PoPs have increased by 5%, so we're in line with our medium-term organic growth guidance, showing the strength of our current operations. Additionally, DAS nodes have increased 6% in the quarter, and we are working hard to make this new activity a significant contributor to Cellnex revenues going forward.
In terms of organic growth drivers, you can see on Slide 7 our view for our new organic PoPs as well as the progress of our decommissioning and build-to-suit program. New PoPs from multi-tenancy are expected to be generated at a rate in line with our guidance, and these quarterly results confirm this trend.
Our decommissioning program now shows a 45% progress thanks to the recent agreement reached to dismantle 400 additional sites, thus providing us with even more visibility on our future organic growth. Progress on our build-to-suit program includes our recent agreement with Bouygues Telecom in France, and we are already taking the first steps in close coordination with our customer.
Before moving to Slide 9 and as a reminder, please note that additional financial information can be obtained from the Investor Relations section of our website, where a detailed Excel file is available.
You can see on this slide the evolution of PoPs and our consolidated tenancy ratio, which increase is mainly explained by consistent organic growth and change of perimeter. As you can see, we have managed to add 1,000 organic PoPs here on a year-by-year basis, with 289 being generated this quarter only, reaching a tenancy ratio of 1.63 if change of perimeter is included.
Also, we are pursuing new organic growth opportunities in all businesses areas, with a special mention to the framework agreement we have recently signed with the fourth mobile operator in Italy which will provide them with full flexibility for their network deployment in the country.
We are also proud to announce a new project for decommissioning of 400 third-party towers. We continue to pursue commercial opportunities in the DAS small cells area, and signed a new contract with T-systems for the provision of land support for Inmarsat on-board communications solution. 
Last but not least, I would like to remind you that Cellnex expects no impact from the second digital dividend, that DTT spectrum is secured and list until 2030, and that we also expect to benefit from new mobile communication services deployed as a result of more spectrum available to operators on 5G.
On the next slide, you can find a comprehensive explanation of our adjusted EBITDA evolution. You can see how the positive impact of the switch on of the new TV channel last year is reinforced by organic growth contribution and change of perimeter, explaining the strong adjusted EBITDA increase in the period of 33%.
Moving to our capital structure on Slide 11. You can see our debt maturities profile as of April with an average maturity of around 6.5 years, no material refinancing required prior to 2022 and a strong protection against potential interest rate increase as a result of the fixed cost nature of our debt. All in all, we have a long-term capital structure in place at attractive terms with EUR 2 billion of liquidity between cash and available credit lines, providing us with full flexibility to optimize available funding alternatives.
Let me please now explain on Slide 12 our recent levered free cash flow generation in the period. I would like to start by highlighting that the cash conversion ratio of EBITDA into recurring levered free cash flow in the period has been a strong 84%. 
Looking now to revenues. The contribution from Telecom Infrastructure Services and broadcasting increased, with a very well contained cost base, leading to an adjusted EBITDA growth of 33% when compared to last year.
Maintenance CapEx is slightly below our guidance due to the phasing. Our change in working capital is trending to neutral. Interest rate reflect our capital structure as of March and its associated coupons, why -- which tax are due later in the year. All in all, we are showing today a 15% revenue growth, which implies more than doubling our adjusted EBITDA growth when compared to last year.
Moving now to our balance sheet on Slide 23. Cellnex leverage for the period has reached 4.3x net debt/annualized EBITDA after investing more than EUR 700 million in the previous months. Compared to December 2016, our balance sheet mostly reflects the increase in debt instruments and its associated cash inflow in the period.
Moving to Slide 14 and as a summary, let me please highlight that. Today, we are presenting again a solid set of results. We are posting a strong and consistent organic growth coupled with our progress on our additional value-creation initiatives, such as the framework agreement with the fourth mobile operator in Italy and a new decommissioning project. And finally, we are reiterating our guidance for the full year 2017.
The next section address several key topics that I believe are self-explanatory, but I am more than happy to answer any questions you may have. So let's please start the Q&A session.

componenttextpreview: It's Simon from Barclays. So I just wondered if you could elaborate a bit on your financial flexibility. Do you still see a lot of scope to be able to do further add deals in future? And then secondly, on -- you mentioned earlier that you wanted to see DA
componenttext: It's Simon from Barclays. So I just wondered if you could elaborate a bit on your financial flexibility. Do you still see a lot of scope to be able to do further add deals in future? And then secondly, on -- you mentioned earlier that you wanted to see DAS come -- become a significant contributor to revenues in future. Could you just talk me through a bit more about your small cell strategy? Because we've seen you do a couple of partnerships recently with JCDecaux and I think the Spanish the real estate company as well. Could you also just comment on how you look at fiber assets? So we're seeing Comcast do it quite with small cells in the U.S., who've bought up quite a few fiber assets in the last year or so. And that was it.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. So regarding the financial flexibility, as you can see, we do have right now EUR 2 billion in cash and available credit lines. These credit lines are long term, so between 3 and 5 years. And also, you know that we have tapped the debt market, the bo
componenttext: Okay. So regarding the financial flexibility, as you can see, we do have right now EUR 2 billion in cash and available credit lines. These credit lines are long term, so between 3 and 5 years. And also, you know that we have tapped the debt market, the bond market, with bond market issuance of 10 years. And on top of that, 2 private placements at -- I think at also 10 and 9 years. So the thing is that the market, the debt market, is giving us -- we have the door open. Our backlog is huge. We're talking about more than EUR 12 billion of backlog. This is recognized by bond investors, and I think that the reason why Cellnex has the flexibility to fund acquisitions with debt. Also bear in mind something, when you have EUR 2 billion of available debt, it's because the perception of the debt community, banks and bankholders, is positive. Otherwise, we wouldn't have this money. And so is it not only my perception of flexibility, it's also the perception of the market regarding Cellnex. Also, as we were seeing in the last -- in the full year results, Cellnex delevered very quickly. And we estimate that at least 0.6x in terms of net debt/EBITDA should decrease Cellnex in 1 year. So this will give us headroom to grow, headroom to fund our debts. You have -- You're second question was CommsCon. And as you know, CommsCon, we -- it's a great opportunity for us. It's opening -- we are opening up the -- not only land market in which CommsCon was already, but also the Spanish market. We have been building up alliance, as you were suggesting before. And you have here the results, I mean, with a strong growth that we hope in the future can go on. We are very active in our core markets, very active with CommsCon, and the results is step-by-step and recognized by clients not only because of the economics of the transaction that we do think makes sense for both sides, but also for the very good quality that we are delivering to clients. It's not only a question of economics, it's also a question of credibility of credentials. And I think CommsCon is building up these credentials and this is being recognized. And I think, Juan Jose, you can explain better than me the second -- the third question.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Simon. On your last question, I guess that as you know, we are still trying to develop our strategy in Europe for small cells and DAS. At this [indiscernible], we are far from consolidating our positions like the ones that Comcast is executing in th
componenttext: Sure, Simon. On your last question, I guess that as you know, we are still trying to develop our strategy in Europe for small cells and DAS. At this [indiscernible], we are far from consolidating our positions like the ones that Comcast is executing in the states. So I guess that in the short term, our approach will be to make use of existing fiber assets, so maybe by reaching agreements with third parties, rather than the executing direct investments. But again, this is something that we are at early stages and will be considered in the future.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017

componenttext: Next question from Mr. Ottavio Adorisio from Societe Generale.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. The first is sort of a follow-up from the one you just answer. On top of the time frame, if you can just elaborate a bit of the economics of this decommission contract. Basically, the cost of decommissions, I believe, is on your sid
componenttext: A couple of questions. The first is sort of a follow-up from the one you just answer. On top of the time frame, if you can just elaborate a bit of the economics of this decommission contract. Basically, the cost of decommissions, I believe, is on your side rather than the client side. And if that's the case, what's the breakeven on this contract, given the contracts? I don't know if you already signed the full contract or just the framework agreement. Just understand when you're going to break even and what sort of return on investments you have on this contract you signing. The second one, it's on the Bouygues side. You signed a contract for -- in February for delivery -- or, delivery, sorry -- for basically 1,800 towers that will be only gradually given to you. So just want to -- you said at that time, I remember you mentioned around 2 years. So given now that you've got a bit more months, if you have a bit more kind of clarity on when these towers will come in. Will the bulk, will be this year? Will be next year? And if the payments are done, that simultaneous when the towers comes in? Or they're paid in advance. And the third, it's on tax. You basically mentioned in the presentations and during the call about the high conversion rates, and then you compare yourself to a number of towers -- TowerCos in Europe, most of them are in Italy. Now given your significant exposure to the market and given the fact that, at least the table you show in your presentations, saying that most of the Italian TowerCos pay in excess of 10% of the EBITDA while yours at the group level is around only 2%. So my question is how long your 2%, it's specifically going to stay at this level? And what sort of framework you believe -- now that you expand into new markets, will that 2% remain as such? So you basically believe that the tax rate could increase or decrease from here?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ottavio, for the question. Let's just start by the last one, and I will go to the other ones. So the tax, and I remember, Ottavio, this question from you at the moment of the IPO. And we have been working on tax since then, and as you can see,
componenttext: Thank you, Ottavio, for the question. Let's just start by the last one, and I will go to the other ones. So the tax, and I remember, Ottavio, this question from you at the moment of the IPO. And we have been working on tax since then, and as you can see, being very consistent with this trend. So we are working on that. We have several things that are being -- several measures that are being implemented which are very basic ones. I don't think this is elaborating strange things, it's just very basic, almost like the amortization, depreciation policy. So assessing in detail every single CapEx we invest, how can be depreciated according to the law and to make sense. Second, our structure, you know that we place our debt in the most -- I will say to you, in the most advantaged place so that we make sense when doing all the investments we carry out. Third, we'll have also comment that we have a patent box mechanism. Cellnex is a company that generates know how. And this knowhow, we set up contracts which are fully compliant with the European directives and allow us to somehow take advantage of the regulation in European countries for companies that foster research and development. Also you know that in some specific countries, we are taking into account the national interest reduction, and also, it's helping us. So it's not only one measure, it's several things that, put it together, allow us to take advantage, allow us to comply with the law and to pay what we have to pay. Nothing more, nothing less. How long? Well, if -- how long? Is the same for everything. It's how long interest rates are going to be like that? How long the organic growth is going to be there? How long -- our base case scenario is that these policies, these different measure we're implementing are long-term measures. I think that this is not something that we take very seriously and always compliance. So -- and therefore, when you are compliance, you don't have to be worried about how long. There is another angle you were saying. Your second question was about Bouygues deal. You are right, we communicate to the market the Bouygues deal was going to be executed throughout the next quarters. It's not going to be executed in 1 day. And why? Because this is the acquisition of assets, it's not the acquisition of shares. If we were talking about acquisition of shares, we would have half pay up on all the money and maybe we would be having EBITDA coming into the company. But also, maybe we were paying more taxes, no? Back to the previous question, the previous answer. So eventually, what we have done is an asset deal. This takes time because we have -- we need a waiver of the landlord, we need to coordinate with a client. It is my feeling that we will obtain the results that we gave you at the full year 2016 presentation, when we gave you the outlook. So limited impact in 2017. We will communicate you up quarter-by-quarter how much we pay, how many towers we receive. Finally, regarding the economics. Again, are the same economics we talk in the IPO. So at the moment, we were saying that roughly speaking in general. And when we sign a contract like this contract that has been signed, is we invest, let's say, EUR 24,000, EUR 25,000, EUR 30,000 per decommission side, and then we have a payback that is fully compliant with our M&A golden rules for unlevered projects, that you know perfectly how these rules are. So we feel comfortable, the breakeven. I think that it takes -- in terms of payback, I cannot be very specific, but this playback is a good payback, yes.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: The first one is related with the announcement that you have made on the framework agreement with the Italian, fourth, MNO. I would like to know at which extent you can provide us some details of the agreement, if that agreement just applies to Italy or a
componenttext: The first one is related with the announcement that you have made on the framework agreement with the Italian, fourth, MNO. I would like to know at which extent you can provide us some details of the agreement, if that agreement just applies to Italy or applies for the markets. If -- when do you expect that agreement to start delivering in terms of earnings. And what is your profile in that agreement? Are you a simple provider, the preferred provider for this Italian MNO? And what is possible? Also regarding the organic growth performance. I would like to discuss -- I will just spend -- we should expect some acceleration of the organic growth in the coming 2 quarters, basically derived from the -- [indiscernible] from the roaming regulation? Roaming is -- the roaming prices in Europe by half, that the early fall in would extend the traffic elasticity to the price, will imply much more traffic in the countries who are net receivers of roamers rumors, and that which just then that is going to be an organic growth lever, particularly, for example, for Spain and Italy, in the coming quarters. My final question is regarding with M&A. And we would just then -- you can also provide us some views, particularly on timing, and any other -- also work on the sunrise tower disposal process.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. So okay, let's go as directed. The first question, yes, well, this is for operator release. We have signed a framework agreement. This framework agreement give us the flexibility, given the flexibility to choose our sites with parameters that are fu
componenttext: Okay. So okay, let's go as directed. The first question, yes, well, this is for operator release. We have signed a framework agreement. This framework agreement give us the flexibility, given the flexibility to choose our sites with parameters that are fully defined and that are coherent with both sides. This is a very important framework agreement for us that situates, positions Cellnex as a key player in the Italian market, as an independent TowerCo, which in our view, is essential; and also give us further opportunities. And this is a first movement in -- what we can see more movements in the organic growth, in the subsequent organic growth. It is not only about PoPs, it's also about engineering services, it's about this -- you cannot see this, like, framework agreement for a PoP, it's a framework agreement for general service for entrance in a new country. That is the case. We are quite prudent in terms -- you're asking when, and we are back to the same answer we gave to you before. We do not see this having an impact in 2019. We are thinking that we will have some impact in 2018. And I'm pretty sure that later in the year, we will update with our views on the outlook of 2018. And at that time, we will be more -- let's say, more open. So far, I think it's a fairly good step. I would say extremely good step in a very good direction and position Cellnex where we want to be as a key independent TowerCo, delivering value for our shareholders and also respecting the path of our clients. You were just -- M&A deals. Well, we have said before we are quite active looking for opportunities that are compliant with our M&A golden rules. These M&A golden rules are quite clear and are quite demanding. So yes, we are involved in different opportunities and we are making progress. If finally, we are successful or not is something that takes time to know. However, I do think that in all the projects that we are right now involved are projects in which Cellnex can implement its knowhow, in which Cellnex shows the competitive advantage based in our master service agreement, the competitive advantage in the level of service that we provide our clients in our -- in the very full term, and also -- term, and also the creative solutions that we can bring into the table. Towering in Europe is starting and we are the first mover here. I think that the other question, [ Paco ], you are better positioned than me to answer.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Fernando. I guess the answer is potentially yes, that we have seen today no indication that this could be the case, at least in the very short term. It makes sense that, again, densification needs and more equipment is needed by operators, so there is som
componenttext: Fernando. I guess the answer is potentially yes, that we have seen today no indication that this could be the case, at least in the very short term. It makes sense that, again, densification needs and more equipment is needed by operators, so there is some scope for us to capture, partially, some of that growth. But it's far too early to say. We have seen nothing changing in this term.

componenttext: Fernando, we cannot be very specific here. What they can say to you is that for us, we have been clear in this in full year 2016 result. But yes, the answer is we are trying to work in different angles here, but not only with this client. So don't think I'm answering specifically about this client. I'm answering about how Cellnex works, okay?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017

componenttext: Next question, from Mr. Pedro Oliveira from BPI.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had some problems hearing the call, so I don't know if I'm going to repeat something. But my first question is regarding your excellent nonrecurrent that you booked in the quarter. I was wondering if you could comment a little bit on the nature and if y
componenttext: I had some problems hearing the call, so I don't know if I'm going to repeat something. But my first question is regarding your excellent nonrecurrent that you booked in the quarter. I was wondering if you could comment a little bit on the nature and if you expect further nonrecurring costs throughout the rest of the year. Also, if you can provide some color on the decline of network service and others in the quarter. And if this is a trend that we can extrapolate for the full year. And one final comment regarding the framework agreement that you just signed with [indiscernible] in Italy, does that -- this agreement imply any kind of exclusivity? Or the operator can also sign other agreements with other net tower operators in Italy or additional?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, regarding -- this is [indiscernible] a very last question. The framework agreement, it's, as we were saying, it's -- we are -- we have set up the foundations for a contract. So it is -- therefore, it's the foundation for potentially contract. And it
componenttext: Yes, regarding -- this is [indiscernible] a very last question. The framework agreement, it's, as we were saying, it's -- we are -- we have set up the foundations for a contract. So it is -- therefore, it's the foundation for potentially contract. And it is very developed. And part, obviously, there is not -- as for -- as of today, there is not exclusivity. But you can say it is already contractualized, fully contractualized everything. This is another step in the good direction, okay? So step-by-step, you will see how this evolves. Regarding network service and others, and I think that this is the -- this is the communication we have, we're obviously being very clear. Network services and others is, again, one business line that should grow following inflation. Maybe if you compare quarter-by-quarter, you can see, it goes down a little bit, it goes up a little bit. So if you do not look at the quarter but you look at the [indiscernible] trends and your projections, inflation is a good driver. It's very similar to broadcasting. So -- stable and have the same path. And finally, the non-recurrent. Non-recurrent -- and we have been, also here, it seems that some items that we seen are not going to be repeated. For instance -- or maybe are non-cash items that do not add anything to the recurrent EBIT -- free cash flow. So here, we have several things. We have M&A, some M&A costs that we have include because of the Bouygues deal. So when we execute M&A deal, there are some costs. That should be when you project, yes, we have some cost. But at the same time, we should have some EBITDA. You shouldn't project these because if you project these costs, you should project more M&A in your projections. Then you have some non-cash items that are the rest of them. And these non-cash items are provisions that we execute in order to renegotiate some contracts in the future. So according to IFRS, when we renegotiate some contracts, we have to recognize a provision. And in the future, you will see the cash flows and the adjustments in the EBIDTA. So this is -- these are one-offs that are not recurrent and we don't think makes sense. In any case, Pedro, and also for the rest of the audience, on the Excel sheet provided, you can find a full breakdown of these elements, of both the M&A expenses which are cash; and then the EUR 6 million, the balance, EUR 6 million, which is our non-cash items. So the full breakdown is provided in the Excel file.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones from my side. First one on the tower decommissioning. So can you confirm that the incremental PoP you expect to get from decommissioning are included in your PoP growth guidance for the year? And if that's the case, then how much of the
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones from my side. First one on the tower decommissioning. So can you confirm that the incremental PoP you expect to get from decommissioning are included in your PoP growth guidance for the year? And if that's the case, then how much of the decommissioning do you -- include in your guidance? First one. And second one on the 2,200 build-to-suit sites, how many you expect to build this year?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the -- on your second question, very specifically, there are 2 deals included in this progress that I will have pictured in this slide. The first one is the 400 sites agreement for Wind. This process has seen a delay because of the merger with the Wind
componenttext: On the -- on your second question, very specifically, there are 2 deals included in this progress that I will have pictured in this slide. The first one is the 400 sites agreement for Wind. This process has seen a delay because of the merger with the Wind and Hutchison in Italy. So the moment that they have a clearer picture on how to deploy their own network, we will have establish [indiscernible] in the field. So that is why the execution has been delayed. [indiscernible] obviously, the agreement remains and it completely up to the customers to come back to us to start deploying this agreement. The second deal included in this progress is the build-to-suit stage associated with the Bouygues transaction we announced at the beginning of this year. This process is already in place, but given the nature, which is we'll start our engineering, we'll start asking for the permits. So it’s a process that takes longer than, obviously, the acquisition, that which is a mistake. So that's why our best case is assuming the contribution of these new towers from 2020, 2022, approximately. So you should see the contribution from these towers at along that time. Not in a very short time.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Regarding the guidance, you are talking about the 3%, 4%, the organic growth has several, several legs. First of all is the pure organic growth. Second is the build-to-suit. And then we have the decommissioning. These 3%, 4%, it's more related to the pure
componenttext: Regarding the guidance, you are talking about the 3%, 4%, the organic growth has several, several legs. First of all is the pure organic growth. Second is the build-to-suit. And then we have the decommissioning. These 3%, 4%, it's more related to the pure organic growth. However, it is true that when you see our growth going a little bit higher, 4% -- in the north of 4%, is because there are other angles that are taking place. I'm pretty sure that, as the build-to-suit program of Bouygues, that [ Juan-Jo ] was explaining, when decommissioning contractualized sites, decommission are rationalized, I'm pretty sure that this growth, 3%, 4%, the growth in terms of PoP will be higher than this. So -- but you know, we tend to be prudent and we somehow think that this 3%, 4% is, when projecting the very long term, this is what you should consider. And in the short term, medium term, it is true that this 3%, 4%, should be somehow upgraded with decommissioning contracts and build-to-suit.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: So just 2 very quick ones left from my side. So the first one is on Slide 19, you mentioned how you calculate IRRs for your M&A and your projects. Can you just give some indication of the -- say, the standard level of leverage you can see to calculate the
componenttext: So just 2 very quick ones left from my side. So the first one is on Slide 19, you mentioned how you calculate IRRs for your M&A and your projects. Can you just give some indication of the -- say, the standard level of leverage you can see to calculate the IRRs. And second question is can you comment a little bit on any possible impact you would expect due to some possible reshuffling of your shareholder structure, due to the offer of Atlantia -- possible offer of Atlantia to buy Abertis stake.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Second question is very easy. No comment. First question and regarding the IRR, the equity IRR. So as you can see here in the slide, what we implement is a project financing at local level, it is nonrecourse. So we'll go to banks. We ask the banks to give
componenttext: Second question is very easy. No comment. First question and regarding the IRR, the equity IRR. So as you can see here in the slide, what we implement is a project financing at local level, it is nonrecourse. So we'll go to banks. We ask the banks to give us the term sheet that define this level of project financing. So how much debt a bank or a pool of banks can give to that project, taking into account the MSA, the OpEx and CapEx, and, taking into account some rational organic growth that we think we can consider. We do not take into account synergies. And also taking into account the tax that have to be paid in the country and also the working capital, and that this MSA and OpEx suppliers require. So the thing is that the banks, taking into account on these give us a quantum of debt; give us the maturity of this debt; the spread of this debt; covenants, if any; and a full look. So essentially, this is how we estimate -- how we estimate the IRRs. So it's fully compliant with any single project in the different countries as any infrastructure player will do.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. I don't know, you probably are not comfortable on commenting that, so you see something like half financing, half equity, half debt, would be something standard? Or you think it varies a lot project by project?
componenttext: Okay. I don't know, you probably are not comfortable on commenting that, so you see something like half financing, half equity, half debt, would be something standard? Or you think it varies a lot project by project?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's project by project. You cannot compare geographies. It's difficult. The easiest answer is what you are suggesting, but we go into the details. We go into the details. So it's not only how much debt they give us -- to us, it's at what cost, and if thi
componenttext: It's project by project. You cannot compare geographies. It's difficult. The easiest answer is what you are suggesting, but we go into the details. We go into the details. So it's not only how much debt they give us -- to us, it's at what cost, and if this cost is tax deductible, is not tax deductible. So it is a little bit more complex than on that. The only thing, Nelson, I can tell you is that is market conditions. So we do not mix our capacity of raising debt at Cellnex with the capacity of raising debt at the project level. So we do not pay any synergy at all.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017

componenttext: We have another question from Mr. Parin Shah from Bank of America.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: So I've got 4, if that's okay. So one is from the growth because I think a degree of confusion on this. The 3% to 4% growth that you previously quoted, now goes up to 4%, and that you're saying is organic. So on top of this, should we be adding something
componenttext: So I've got 4, if that's okay. So one is from the growth because I think a degree of confusion on this. The 3% to 4% growth that you previously quoted, now goes up to 4%, and that you're saying is organic. So on top of this, should we be adding something before the decommissioning? Or because obviously, your growth guidance longer term is into 2019, in the coming years, the decommissioning will be happening. So is it 3% to 4% plus something or not? The second is just on Iliad. And I appreciate you're probably quite sensitive to adding any details around that, but just from your end do you have a clear understanding of what the value of this contract is because obviously when we were looking at this look at tenants -- value per tenant, potential rollout for Iliad, there's a lot of variables in that. And I understand this is early-stage framework agreement. But do you have a clear kind of floor for what the value should be? The third question is just around Atlantia, Abertis or just more broadly on that. Are you comfortable with Abertis or whoever shareholder happens to be exiting your company? Or do you feel you need some kind of anchor shareholder in your shareholding structure? And the final question is just on M&A more generally. Are there any deals on the horizon that are quite large because I know your strategy is to start off small, build up? Are there any deals in the radar that are quite large that would necessitate an equity raising? And are you comfortable with doing something like that?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Parin, quick answer on your first question, the answer is yes. We are now more accurate on the organic growth guidance on how we see, maybe long term, in terms of organic growth. So that's how we are setting it now with 4%, which will be complemented with
componenttext: Parin, quick answer on your first question, the answer is yes. We are now more accurate on the organic growth guidance on how we see, maybe long term, in terms of organic growth. So that's how we are setting it now with 4%, which will be complemented with the commission of opportunity. So new PoPs, new P-O-P, is coming from the commissioning, will be on top of this 4%.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, and -- okay. So the value of this contract, this is not -- this is a framework agreement. So now this is our first step. Well, first step. This is a very good step in the very good direction in order to contractualize the services. The thing h
componenttext: Okay. Well, and -- okay. So the value of this contract, this is not -- this is a framework agreement. So now this is our first step. Well, first step. This is a very good step in the very good direction in order to contractualize the services. The thing here is when you talk about value, you know that we cannot be here more explicit. But taking into account that this is a win-win agreement for both sides, that it's a very comprehensive agreement and that brings to the table all the value that are independent or what we can put into the table. So I cannot be more explicit like that. As we were saying before, as the quarters comes in, we will guide you on this value step by step or how this comes into our EBITDA. You are talking about -- again, about Abertis and Atlantia deal, well, listen. Yesterday, we have our general assembly meeting. And the chairman of the company was clear. He's satisfied with Cellnex, and that's all I can comment. I cannot go beyond that. I think Cellnex is a company that can bring a lot of value to the table, so I am fully convinced. And I'm pretty sure that any shareholder that has opportunity to join us recognize this value, and therefore, will be -- any shareholder will be very commensurate and accurate about the -- on decision-making process. Finally, regarding any deals. Again, back to the one of the first questions, the financial flexibility. We'll have a lot of tools to fund the deals and a huge backlog, by the way. So let's go step by step, and you will see what we can do, what we cannot do. We have a very demanding [indiscernible]. So it's not easy to execute deals. It's not impossible. You know that this year, we have already presented very important deals for you. Pretty sure that we will go on working and presenting to you things that make sense for the shareholders.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. That's very clear. Just on the growth, a quick follow up. So the 3% to 4% and now 4% because you have greater clarity, is that around Iliad or something else? And then more generally, when you start adding decommissioning tenants, are you going to
componenttext: Great. That's very clear. Just on the growth, a quick follow up. So the 3% to 4% and now 4% because you have greater clarity, is that around Iliad or something else? And then more generally, when you start adding decommissioning tenants, are you going to report an organic, plus decommissioning, plus M&A, et cetera? So there will be a separate amount for the amount of decommissioning, that's you -- or tenants, sorry, that you're bringing on.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Listen, Parin, actually, we have comment -- we have commented the guideline. We -- I would repeat again. So let's wait a little bit. We have been clear in your short term, medium term. And this 3%, 4% should be a floor on top of that build to suit. And on
componenttext: Listen, Parin, actually, we have comment -- we have commented the guideline. We -- I would repeat again. So let's wait a little bit. We have been clear in your short term, medium term. And this 3%, 4% should be a floor on top of that build to suit. And on top of that, the commissioning should be a good proxy in the long term, the 3%, 4% makes sense. And this is our best estimate right now. It's in line with what we said to you in full year results -- you do know perfectly, you do know perfectly that we are a prudent company. We could here overestimate everything, is not our style. We go step-by-step delivery and being credible. So we feel very comfortable with this growth we have given in the year, in this quarter. We think it's very sustainable and in the future, we are quite positive.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Next question, from Mr. Giles Thorne from Jefferies.
componenttext: Next question, from Mr. Giles Thorne from Jefferies.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had 3 questions, please. And starting with Switzerland, I appreciate there's a process ongoing and you can't be specific, but what it would be interesting to hear is, as you look across your existing European operations and then you look at Switzerland,
componenttext: I had 3 questions, please. And starting with Switzerland, I appreciate there's a process ongoing and you can't be specific, but what it would be interesting to hear is, as you look across your existing European operations and then you look at Switzerland, where exactly would you rank Switzerland as a market opportunity, be it from a market structure or existing coverage or progressive nature of the M&As, whatever it may be? Where would Switzerland sits in your overall ranking of attractiveness of market? Secondly, back on the Iliad agreement. It's a very quick one. Why is this a framework agreement and not a contract? Any comment there would be useful. And then the third question is a bit more of a long-term vision around the sector. And then as we -- specifically, as we see mobile network innovation constantly progress and more and more of the network intelligence virtualize and go into the cloud, it feels like there could be a scenario where what we called active equipment today could actually become much more passive in nature, and therefore, sit more comfortably in the hands of a TowerCo. It feels like this could be a very long-term opportunity. Is that a vision of the way mobile technology is progressing that you share or think about or talk about almost at all? That was it.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Giles, on your third growth question, the -- we fully agree. It is true that we are still trying to establish control of Iliad in terms of outsourcing passive infrastructure, although [ we are getting pretty familiar with progress ]. You might have the im
componenttext: Giles, on your third growth question, the -- we fully agree. It is true that we are still trying to establish control of Iliad in terms of outsourcing passive infrastructure, although [ we are getting pretty familiar with progress ]. You might have the impression that we are still far from making operators comfortable in terms of sharing active equipment, but the rationale is sadly the same. So we fully agree. And when the opportunity arises, we will be there. Remember that our legacy business in Spain has been for many, many years the broadcasting business, but we do everything. So we invest in the active equipment, we manage the whole network, so we do have the experience. We combine different contents in just one signal. So this is something that's also feasible from a technical perspective and translate in this approach for the mobile communications world. So we are going to do so. It's a matter of operators being softer to this idea in the future. So happy to work in that direction?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. You have the question about Switzerland. For us, it's not a country. It's not only the country the key driver on a deal, when we accept a deal. The key driver is MSA. So let's talk about MSA. Let's talk about what independent TowerCo can do in a cou
componenttext: Okay. You have the question about Switzerland. For us, it's not a country. It's not only the country the key driver on a deal, when we accept a deal. The key driver is MSA. So let's talk about MSA. Let's talk about what independent TowerCo can do in a country, but, the most importantly with the client. And this is what we assess in all the countries in Europe in which we come across, with a deal. So why -- what can I bring to the table today and tomorrow? So I'm quite reluctant to say to you, well, we like this country because of this characteristic. I will say to you we like this contract because this contract allowed me to sit down with my client, to propose to my client these solutions to be -- to become a partner with my client. And from this perspective, the answer is yes. We are assessing several opportunities in Europe that I think make sense from -- in that perspective -- in perspective. And from this angle, we do think that tendency is unique -- it's quite unique. Because we have all ingredients, all the tools to give services in that tailor-made situation to our clients.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then finally, on the -- and rather guess Iliad, why it's not a contract? Why would that be interesting then?
componenttext: Understood. And then finally, on the -- and rather guess Iliad, why it's not a contract? Why would that be interesting then?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, because this is a process. First of all, you have to set up the foundations of potential agreements, okay. And then obviously, here, you sit down again to understand the needs, to build that. And step by step, we crystallize -- we will crystallize. I
componenttext: Yes, because this is a process. First of all, you have to set up the foundations of potential agreements, okay. And then obviously, here, you sit down again to understand the needs, to build that. And step by step, we crystallize -- we will crystallize. If this is a win-win agreement that we think is a win-win agreement, we will crystallize this in contracts and value. But this is a process, so don't think that this is the end. This is a good step in the very good direction that only a tower -- independent tower company can do in such a big way, okay. There can be other TowerCos that can do something similar, but we'll be always smaller. We'll be always slowlier (sic) [ slower ]. And here, we try some categories framework agreement, we have the foundations to do something more. Let's go step by step.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Understood. If I could just do a quick follow-up, and it seems to me a lot of the rhetoric has moved away from -- you've driven the message away from infrastructure services and to -- I'm sorry, to infrastructure services from just kind of rental services
componenttext: Understood. If I could just do a quick follow-up, and it seems to me a lot of the rhetoric has moved away from -- you've driven the message away from infrastructure services and to -- I'm sorry, to infrastructure services from just kind of rental services. And as you're participating in these M&A processes, do you get the sense that some of your TowerCo peers are also pitching in the same way? So you offer a bundled services agreement with engineering thrown in or whatever it may be, which sounds differentiated. But is it actually differentiated? Or are your TowerCo peers in this processes also pitching themselves in a similar way?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, beating is possible. That all of us we beat in the same way, but reaching agreements is different. So you can beat yourself, yes. You are right. You can do something coherent or to tell the equity story or to tell -- to explain a customer's story, w
componenttext: Well, beating is possible. That all of us we beat in the same way, but reaching agreements is different. So you can beat yourself, yes. You are right. You can do something coherent or to tell the equity story or to tell -- to explain a customer's story, which is you can beat it, that's easy. What is difficult is to somehow crystallize this into a contract, into a framework agreement, into value. And then here, yes, I can tell you, in every single process we come across in which Cellnex has the opportunity to sit down and to elaborate while the results are there and we feel that back to France, 2016 December, January 2017, you will know that we lost FPS. FPS was being sold down by infrastructure fund. For us, it's difficult. It's difficult to win. It's more difficult to win in this situation compared to others, in which you can sit down, you can elaborate, you can bring a new contract from scratch. And this is again, this tailor-made contract agreement is our competitive advantage. And this is -- that's our reality, so -- and in this regard, we are alone, so far along.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: We have another question from [ Andreas DeLourdes ] from [ Campju Capital ].
componenttext: We have another question from [ Andreas DeLourdes ] from [ Campju Capital ].

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have a few questions. As part of your Shere on weak deals, did you agree to dismantle any sites? And if so, how many? Question number two, what do you think is the cost of building a tower in Europe? For instance, a country like France? Question number
componenttext: I have a few questions. As part of your Shere on weak deals, did you agree to dismantle any sites? And if so, how many? Question number two, what do you think is the cost of building a tower in Europe? For instance, a country like France? Question number three, could you explain the EUR 27 million you spent in expansion and other CapEx during the quarter? And does that include a EUR 6 million payment to Abertis for canceling the office lease in Madrid? And lastly, why did your intangible assets go up by EUR 370 million in Q1?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, listen, let's go step by step. On the first question, the answer is no. That will remain very clear, this is our first stage in order to transfer existing assets and the second stage leading to greater new infrastructure. So there is no dismantle --
componenttext: Well, listen, let's go step by step. On the first question, the answer is no. That will remain very clear, this is our first stage in order to transfer existing assets and the second stage leading to greater new infrastructure. So there is no dismantle -- dismantling agreement. On your second question, the cost might be quite wide depending on the country, depending on the technology mostly of the site you want to build, depends if it's a rural tower or urban site. But it might be ranging from maybe 40,000 to 100,000, roughly. Again, that depends on the topology of the office site that wants to be building. Your third question. Your third question was about the -- I think you said if you can tell me in my balance sheet, you said that the assets had been increased by EUR 350 million, I think you have said, no?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: That was question number four, intangible assets were up by EUR 370 million.
componenttext: That was question number four, intangible assets were up by EUR 370 million.

componenttext: Listen, I can -- let's go to Page 13 where you can see here the balance sheet. Okay. So I am here going through fixed assets, there is no such a big change. And the other question was about, I guess, that has to do with -- actually a 2016 question that is -- is that correct, regarding some provisions on the courtesy mandate, is that correct?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: No. That was the EUR 27 million you spent during the quarter as part of your catalyst statement in your company and so broken down by expansion CapEx and other net cash flows. And does that include a EUR 6 million payment to Abertis for canceling the offi

componenttext: [indiscernible] a question for [indiscernible], but let us please -- that will change your specific concern, I'll come back to you, okay? On your first question, the economics are slightly different. Bear in mind that we're now operator in the context of the Galata transaction. For example, they sell towers. We pay for that portfolio in exchange for efficient cash flows. Build-to-suit economics might be a bit different. Usually what we include in this business plan is the construction cost. The returns are similar, but also the associated fees coming from the [indiscernible] might be different. So in terms of return the spirit of the whole transaction is exactly the same, but economics per tower are different. On the 2,200 target for build to suit, it is true that the progress states the 400 towers agreement with WIND, and also there we're seeing agreement with telecom for 1,200 towers. The rest is part of the target, not contracted yet. So obviously this is an opportunity that we still need to pursue.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, and I’m Cellnex Head of Investor Relations. I would like to thank you all for joining us today for our H1 2017 results conference call. I'm joined today by José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, who will
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, and I’m Cellnex Head of Investor Relations. I would like to thank you all for joining us today for our H1 2017 results conference call. I'm joined today by José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, who will lead today's presentation. We have earlier posted our presentation which we will refer to throughout our prepared remarks. And then we'll open the line for a Q&A session.
The total duration scheduled for this session is 1 hour so after this time, I will be at the company's disposal to answer any remaining questions. So now, please, José Manuel.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones of the period on Slide 4.We have again posted a solid set of results in line with consensus, and we continue to reach a strategic partnershi
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you so much for your time today. Let me please start by highlighting the main milestones of the period on Slide 4.
We have again posted a solid set of results in line with consensus, and we continue to reach a strategic partnership with key European players. We continue to generate a strong organic growth, in line with our guidance. We see the European tower outsourcing process accelerating and we are glad to announce a new agreement, the extension of our cooperation with Bouygues Telecom in France by acquiring 600 additional sites. Two months ago, we entered into strategic partnership with Sunrise. Based on our unique Master Service Agreement, which we are expecting to close in the coming weeks. And we have also strengthened our position in Italy by acquiring the remaining 10% stake in Galata, previously owned by Wintry. We are improving the visibility of our future organic growth in the context of our strategic agreement with Sunrise through a build to suit program for 400 sites, 200 DAS nodes contracted and a right to match under full support. Sunrise on its future small cells and DAS needs in Switzerland.
We continue to lead a unique value proposition in the European tower landscape based on tailored MSAs, a Full Network Service approach, neutrality and a very strong relationship with our customers with a long-term view.
We are also reaffirming our 2017 guidance. We should have seen good Cellnex future launch contribution upon closing.
On Slide 5, you can see the strong performance of our key value metrics, with adjusted EBITDA growing annually more than 20% and recurring level free cash flow per share growing 17% annually over the last couple of years.
Moving to Slide 6. Total PoPs have increased 22%, and our consolidated customer ratio by 5%. These metrics include the contribution of both organic growth and the change of perimeter in the period. If we focus on organic growth only, PoPs have increased by 5%, therefore about our medium-term guidance, showing the strength of our current operations.
DAS nodes have also increased by 10% in the semester, and we are working hard to make these new sector a significant contributor to Cellnex' future revenues.
In this context, we are happy to announce that we have signed our first small cells project in Spain. By reaching an agreement with Atlético Madrid football club for the rollout of an exclusive DAS network at their new stadium.
If we move now to Slide 7, you can see a summary and the main characteristics of our more recent growth activity. As a summary, we have managed to increase our footprint by close to 6,500 towers in 6 months only, when all the different stages are completed. As mentioned earlier, we have reached an agreement with Bouygues Telecom to acquire up to 600 additional top sites. This is an extension of the agreement signed earlier this year. The 4 under the same terms, and these additional sites will be transferred into Cellnex brands no later than 2020. This new agreement represents an extension of our partnership with Bouygues Telecom only 6 months after our initial agreement for the 3,500 sites.
In the Netherlands, we have executed a small transaction at an attractive valuation to continue growing in the country, and we have strengthened our position in Italy by acquiring the remaining 10% stake in Galata.
Finally, we are expected to close the acquisition of Swiss Towers in Q3 2017. This agreement is based on a unique Master Service Agreement and sets the condition of a strategic partnership with Sunrise. We're also securing organic growth through the 400 sites build to suit program and our right to match and the -- to support Sunrise small cells and DAS rollout in the country.
All of these deals, together, allow us to further expand into attractive markets, extend our relationship with key partners and strengthen our value proposition based on our -- on the Master Service Agreement.
On Slide 8, you can see that the result of the geographical diversification strategy with more than half of our adjusted EBITDA to be generated outside Spain. We are always talking on a pro forma basis. Cellnex has just begun the key player in the European tower landscape.
Moving to Slide 10. I'm talking now about the business performance of the company. You can see the evolution of PoPs and our consolidated customer ratio, with increases mainly explained by consistent organic growth and change of perimeter.
We have managed to have more than 1,000 organic PoP on a year-by-year basis, with 557 PoPs being generated this last semester, and reaching a customer ratio of 1.64, including change of perimeter. Additionally, we are looking for new organic growth opportunities in all areas of activity. Our organic growth is above our guidance. Our decommissioning process stands at 45%, and we have reached 91% of our build to suit target.
We continue to assess opportunities based on a Full Network Service approach so that we can crystallize our competitive advantage, our Master Service Agreement. We are implementing our framework agreement with the fourth mobile network operator in Italy, and closely interacting in order to meet their needs. Please note that a similar approach is being assessed in France with our clients. We have kicked off the 5G city project, which aims at designing and demonstrating in operational conditions a 5G network in several European cities.
And finally, we have recently signed our first small cells project in Spain by reaching an agreement with Atlético Madrid football club for their rollout of an exclusive DAS network at their new stadium. Our contract has a duration of 10 years, and it will be the first stadium in Spain capable of offering a real mobile broadband experience to all the spectators.
Moving to Slide 11, here you can find a detailed explanation of our adjusted EBITDA performance. You can see how the positive impact of the new TV channel last year is reinforced by the contribution of organic growth and efficiencies as well as by change of perimeter. This explains the strong adjusted EBITDA growth in the period of 25%, which is even superior to our growth of revenues by 12%.
Moving to our capital structure on Slide 12. You can see our debt maturities profile as of today. Our structure has an average maturity of around 6.5 years. There is no material refinancing required before 2022, and we have a strong protection against a changing interest rate environment as a result of the combination of fixed rates and very long-term maturities.
In summary, we have a long-term capital structure in place at a very attractive terms. With available liquidity between cash at hand and available credit lines accounting for more than EUR 1.5 billion and providing us with plenty of flexibility to optimize available funding alternatives.
Let me please now move on Slide 13, where you can see our recurring levered free cash flow for the period. I would like to start by highlighting that the cash conversion ratio of EBITDA into recurring levered free cash flow in the period has been a very strong 83%. Regarding revenues, the contribution from Telecom Infrastructure Services and broadcasting increased, with a very well-contained cost base is leading to an adjusted EBITDA growth of 25%, when compared to the same period of last year. Maintenance CapEx is in line with our guidance. Our change in working capital trends to neutral. Interest base reflect our capital structure as of June, and taxes reflect the payments scheduled in the year as well as our management measures in place.
All in all, we are showing today a 12% revenue growth, which implies more than doubling our adjusted EBITDA growth when compared to the last year performance.
Moving now to our balance sheet on Slide 14. Cellnex leverage for the period reaches 4.6x net debt annualized adjusted EBITDA, including the contribution from all closed transactions, both in debt and adjusted EBITDA. Compared to December 2016, our balance sheet mostly reflects the increase in debt instruments and its associated cash inflow, with proceeds to be used for the acquisition of the remaining stake in Galata, the closing of Swiss Towers deal and the transfer of sites from Bouygues Telecom.
Moving to Slide 15 and as a summary, let me please highlight that we are presenting again a very solid set of results. We are posting a strong and consistent organic growth capital, with progress on our additional value creation alternatives -- initiatives. We are seeing an increased momentum in the European tower outsourcing process, as proved by we have been able to extend our relationship with key European players. And finally, we are reiterating our guidance for the year, which will need to be adjusted upwards with Swiss Towers contribution when this deal is finally closed.
The following section is the frequently asked questions section addresses several high-level topics that I believe you are raising very often to us. But anyway, I am more than happy -- we are more than happy to answer any questions you may have, so let's please open the line for any questions you may have.

So please, Alex.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. The investment to the Atlético Madrid one, the stadium, we try to because we are mixing technologies. And I think previously you already illustrated the difference between DAS and small cell. We should recall that, that installation is going to be
componenttext: Sure. The investment to the Atlético Madrid one, the stadium, we try to because we are mixing technologies. And I think previously you already illustrated the difference between DAS and small cell. We should recall that, that installation is going to be a DAS, distributed antenna systems. There are hundreds of antennas but the unit that we agreed as a reporting unit because sometimes difficult is the nodes. So it's going to be above north of 100 nodes, the installation of one in the stadium.

So I guess, that we will continue to try and implement this sort of alternatives if it makes sense for both parties in the future.

componenttext: Thank you, Parin. On your second question, the answer is no.
